<Subject Name>Basic Probability </Subject Name>  
<Question>In a box of 10 colored balls, 3 are red. What is the probability of picking a red ball?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( \frac{3}{10} \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 3 \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the sin graph relates to the tan function
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Graphs of Trigonometric Functions </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Trigonometry </Subject Name>
<Question>Identify the graph of the function \( y = \sin(x) \): </Question> 
<Correct Answer>The graph of \( y = \sin(x) \) is a smooth periodic wave starting at the origin, rising to 1 at \( \frac{\pi}{2} \), falling to 0 at \( \pi \), going to -1 at \( \frac{3\pi}{2} \), and returning to 0 at \( 2\pi \). It repeats every \( 2\pi \). </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The graph of \( y = \sin(x) \) has vertical asymptotes and repeats every \( \pi \), similar to \( y = \tan(x) \). </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not understand how to simplify fractions
response:
<Construct Name> $$Converting improper fractions to mixed numbers$$ </Construct Name>

<Subject Name> $$Fraction Arithmetic$$ </Subject Name>

<Question> $$Convert the improper fraction \( \frac{22}{8} \) to a mixed number in its simplest form.$$ </Question>

<Correct Answer> $$2 \frac{3}{4}$$ </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer> $$2 \frac{7}{8}$$ </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks the area of a sector is theta/360 x r x pi (forgetting the radius is squared)
response:
<Construct Name>Area of a Circular Sector</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry</Subject Name>

<Question>A sector of a circle has a central angle of 60° and a radius of 5 cm. Calculate the area of the sector.</Question>

<Correct Answer>The area of the sector is calculated as follows: \(\text{Area} = \frac{\theta}{360} \times \pi \times r^2\), where \(\theta = 60°\) and \(r = 5 \text{ cm}\).
\[
\text{Area} = \frac{60}{360} \times \pi \times 5^2 = \frac{1}{6} \times \pi \times 25 = \frac{25\pi}{6} \approx 13.09 \text{ cm}^2
\]</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The area of the sector is mistakenly calculated as: \(\text{Area} = \frac{\theta}{360} \times \pi \times r\), where \(\theta = 60°\) and \(r = 5 \text{ cm}\).
\[
\text{Area} = \frac{60}{360} \times \pi \times 5 = \frac{1}{6} \times \pi \times 5 = \frac{5\pi}{6} \approx 2.62 \text{ cm}^2
\]</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes an upward line has a negative gradient
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding and Calculating Gradient of a Line </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Analytic Geometry </Subject Name>

<Question>Determine the gradient of the line that passes through the points \( A(2, 3) \) and \( B(5, 11) \). </Question>

<Correct Answer>The gradient \( m \) is calculated using the formula \( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} \). So here, \( m = \frac{11 - 3}{5 - 2} = \frac{8}{3} \). The gradient is positive, indicating the line slopes upwards from left to right. </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The gradient \( m \) is incorrectly perceived as negative because of the upward slope, leading to \( m = -\frac{11 - 3}{5 - 2} = -\frac{8}{3} \). This reflects the misconception that an upward slope results in a negative gradient. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes that when a shape is enlarged, the area rather than the scale factor is squared
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding the relationship between scale factor and area in enlargements </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry and Measurement </Subject Name>

<Question>A rectangle has an area of 12 square units. If the rectangle is enlarged by a scale factor of 3, what will the new area of the rectangle be?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The new area of the rectangle will be \( 12 \times 3^2 = 108 \) square units. </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The new area of the rectangle will be \( 12 \times 3 = 36 \) square units. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks 0.3 = 1/3
response:
<Construct Name>Converting between decimals and fractions </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Decimals and Fractions </Subject Name>
<Question>Amira is working on simplifying the following expression: \( 0.3 + \frac{1}{3} \).
What is the simplified form of her expression in fraction form? </Question>
<Correct Answer>\(\frac{3}{10} + \frac{1}{3} = \frac{9}{30} + \frac{10}{30} = \frac{19}{30}\) </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\(0.3 + \frac{1}{3} = \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{3} = \frac{2}{3}\) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When solving simultaneous equations, thinks you only transform the term that is being eliminated, rather than the whole equation.
response:
<Construct Name>Manipulate both equations so that they are in a form to be added or subtracted </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Simultaneous Equations </Subject Name>

<Question>Ananya wants to eliminate \( x \) from these simultaneous equations.
\(\begin{array}{l}
4 x-5 y=20 \\
5 x-3 y=25
\end{array}\)

First, she will transform both of them to get them in an appropriate form.
Which of the following is a correct transformation? </Question> 

<Correct Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}20 x-25 y=100 \\ 20 x-12 y=100\end{array} \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}20 x-5 y=20 \\ 20 x-3 y=25\end{array} \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Adds rather than subtracts when using Pythagoras to find a shorter side
response:
<Construct Name>Use Pythagorean Theorem to find side lengths of right triangles </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Geometry - Right Triangles </Subject Name>
<Question>Given a right triangle with a hypotenuse of 10 units and one leg of 6 units, find the length of the other leg. </Question>
<Correct Answer>\( \begin{array}{l} c^2 = a^2 + b^2 \\ 10^2 = 6^2 + b^2 \\ 100 = 36 + b^2 \\ b^2 = 64 \\ b = \sqrt{64} \\ b = 8 \text{ units} \end{array} \) </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( \begin{array}{l} c^2 = a^2 + b^2 \\ 10^2 = 6^2 + b^2 \\ 100 = 36 + b^2 \\ 100 = 36 + (\sqrt{b^2})^2 \\ \sqrt{100-36} = b \\ \sqrt{64} = b \\ b = 10 \text{ units} \end{array} \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not understand that 2n represents an even number
response:
<Construct Name>Identify and classify numbers as odd or even </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Number Theory Basics </Subject Name>  
<Question>Is the product of the expressions \(2n\) and \(m\) odd or even? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>The product is even because \(2n\) represents an even number, and the product of an even number with any integer \(m\) is always even.</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The product is odd because \(m\) is odd, and \(2n\) doesn't necessarily mean an even number.</Incorrect Answer>  


<Construct Name>Understanding properties of integers </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Introduction to Algebraic Expressions </Subject Name>  
<Question>If \(n\) is an integer, what can you say about the quantity \(2n\) in terms of parity? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\(2n\) is always even because it is a multiple of 2.</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\(2n\) can be either even or odd depending on the parity of \(n\).</Incorrect Answer>  


<Construct Name>Explain divisibility rules and number properties </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Divisibility and Multiples </Subject Name>  
<Question>For an integer \(n\), what is the parity of \(2n + 1\)? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\(2n + 1\) is always odd because \(2n\) is even and adding 1 to an even number results in an odd number.</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\(2n + 1\) can be either odd or even depending on the value of \(n\).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks the gradient of a line is found from 2 points by finding the length of that line between those points
response:
<Construct Name>Determine the gradient of a line segment given two distinct points</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Coordinate Geometry</Subject Name>  
<Question>Find the gradient of the line segment joining the points \((2, 3)\) and \((5, 7)\).</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The correct gradient is \(\frac{7 - 3}{5 - 2} = \frac{4}{3}.\)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The misconception leads to interpreting the gradient as the length of the line segment, calculated by the distance formula \(\sqrt{(5 - 2)^2 + (7 - 3)^2} = \sqrt{9 + 16} = 5.\)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, treats that as the total
response:

<Correct Answer>\( 24 \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 18.75 \) </Incorrect Answer>  

Misconception: In ratio questions where one side of the ratio is given, some students mistakenly treat that given amount as the total, instead of understanding it as just one part in the ratio. This misunderstanding may occur due to a focus on the given quantity without considering its role relative to the total sum of parts in the ratio context.

<Question>Determine whether the following triangles are similar: Triangle ABC with sides \(3, 4, 5\) and Triangle DEF with sides \(6, 8, 10\).</Question>

response:
<Construct Name>Factorise a single bracket containing a linear expression by taking out a common factor (e.g., 4)</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Factorising Linear Expressions</Subject Name>

<Question>What should replace the star and pentagon when this expression is fully factorised? \( 12x + 16 \equiv {\bigstar}(\bigtriangleup x + \bigcirc) \)</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=4 \\ \bigtriangleup =3 \\ \bigcirc=4 \end{array} \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=12 \\ \bigtriangleup =1 \\ \bigcirc=\frac{4}{3} \end{array} \) </Incorrect Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The perimeter of the square is \( 20 \) centimetres, which is \( 20,000 \) millimetres.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not know parallel lines have equal gradients
response:
<Construct Name>Determining the Equation of a Parallel Line</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Line Equations and Slopes</Subject Name>  
<Question>A line is given by the equation \( y = 3x + 2 \). Write the equation of a line parallel to this one that passes through the point \((1, 4)\).</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The slope of the given line is \(3\). A parallel line will have the same slope, \(3\). Using the point-slope form: \( y - 4 = 3(x - 1) \). Thus, the equation is \( y = 3x + 1 \).</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The slope of the parallel line is unknown, so the equation cannot be determined without further information.</Incorrect Answer>

<Question>Given the data set: \(7, 9, 15, 21, 24, 30, 32\),

MisconceptionName: Does not understand how to subtract algebraic fractions
response:
<Construct Name>Subtracting algebraic fractions where the denominators are quadratic expressions, eg (x^2+2) and (x^2-4), and the numerators are polynomials with multiple terms</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject Name>

<Question>Simplify the expression by combining the fractions:
\[
\frac{3x + 5}{x^2 - 4} - \frac{2x - 1}{x^2 + 2}
\]</Question>

<Correct Answer>\[\frac{(3x + 5)(x^2 + 2) - (2x - 1)(x^2 - 4)}{(x^2 - 4)(x^2 + 2)} = \frac{3x^3 + 6x + 10 - (2x^3 - 8x + x - 4)}{(x^2 - 4)(x^2 + 2)} = \frac{x^3 + 7x + 14}{(x^2 - 4)(x^2 + 2)}\]</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\[\frac{3x + 5 - (2x - 1)}{x^2 - 4 + x^2 + 2} = \frac{x + 6}{2x^2 - 2}\]</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not know the term numerator
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Fractions</Construct Name>

<Correct Answer>The numerator is 3.</Correct Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes you cannot find the angle size in a pie chart when given its percentage value
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Angles in a Pie Chart</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Pie Chart Analysis</Subject Name>  
<Question>The pie chart shows the distribution of time spent on various activities during a day: Sleeping 33.3%, Working 25%, Leisure 16.7%, Eating 8.3%, and Other activities 16.7%. What is the angle size for the "Working" section of the pie chart?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The angle size for the "Working" section is 90 degrees. (Calculation: 25% of 360 degrees = 0.25 * 360 = 90 degrees)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>You cannot find the angle size because the pie chart only provides percentage values, not angles.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Mixes up constant and coefficient in a worded substitution problem
response:
<Construct Name>Substitution in Algebraic Expressions</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Algebraic Evaluation and Substitution</Subject Name>
<Question>A formula for calculating the total cost \( C \) in dollars of buying \( n \) tickets is given by: 

\[ C = 10n + 5 \]

If you purchase 3 tickets, what is the total cost?</Question>
<Correct Answer>The total cost is \( 35 \mathrm{~dollars} \). </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The total cost is \( 45 \mathrm{~dollars} \) (incorrect substitution by misidentifying the constant and substituting \( 3 \) for both \( n \) and the constant term).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not recognise the corresponding sides in similar shapes or enlargements

<Question> Triangle \( \triangle ABC \) is similar to triangle \( \triangle DEF \). Given that \( AB = 6 \, \mathrm{cm} \), \( AC = 8 \, \mathrm{cm} \), and \( DE = 9 \, \mathrm{cm} \), find the length of side \( DF \).

![Two triangles, the smaller labeled ABC and the larger labeled DEF. Triangle ABC has sides AB = 6 cm, AC = 8 cm and triangle DEF has side DE = 9 cm with side DF marked with a question mark.]() </Question> 

<Correct Answer> \( 12 \, \mathrm{cm} \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer> \( 9 \, \mathrm{cm} \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes multiplication is not commutative
response:
<Construct Name>Solving for a Variable Using Multiplication</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Algebraic Equations and Expressions</Subject Name>

<Question>Jessie is solving the equation \( 4x = 12 \) and decides to multiply by \( \frac{1}{4} \) on both sides to solve for \( x \). 

Jessie claims that multiplying by \( \frac{1}{4} \) on the left side is different from multiplying by \( \frac{1}{4} \) on the right side. 

Is Jessie's claim true? If not, solve for \( x \).</Question>

<Correct Answer>Jessie's claim is not true. Multiplying by the same number on both sides does not change the equality. The solution is:
\[
x = \frac{12}{4} = 3
\]</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Jessie's claim is true, so we cannot simply multiply by the inverse multiplier and get the same result. Therefore, no definitive solution can be solved using this method.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes unrelated acute/obtuse angles in a diagram are supplementary
response:

<Subject Name>$$Geometry$$</Subject Name>

<Correct Answer>$$\angle BED = 60^\circ$$</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>$$\angle BED = 60^\circ + 180^\circ = 240^\circ$$</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks x = ? is a horizontal line through ?
response:
<Construct Name>Determine the coordinates of intersection between a vertical line and a given function</Construct Name>

<Incorrect Answer>(1, 3)</Incorrect Answer>  

Misconception: Students may confuse \( x = 1 \), a vertical line, with the y-coordinate of the intersection. The correct approach is to substitute \( x = 1 \) into the function to determine \( y \).

<Subject Name>Surface Area of Cylinders</Subject Name>

<Question>Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of a cylinder with a radius of 5 cm and a height of 10 cm, in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \)?</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 2 \times \pi \times 5 \times (5 + 10) \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( \pi \times 5^2 \times 10 \)</Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Calculate the surface area of a sphere where the radius is given in the same units</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Surface Area of Spheres</Subject Name>

<Question>Which calculation would give you the surface area of a sphere with a radius of 6 cm in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \)?</Question>

<Subject Name>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject Name>

<Question>What is the total surface area of a rectangular prism with length 8 cm, width 5 cm, and height 3 cm?</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 2 \times [(8 \times 5) + (5 \times 3) + (8 \times 3)] \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 8 \times 5 \times 3 \)</Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Identify the correct calculation for the lateral surface area of a cone where the radius and slant height are given</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Surface Area of Cones</Subject Name>

<Question>Which of the following calculations would give you the lateral surface area of a cone with a radius of 4 cm and a slant height of 9 cm, in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \)?</Question>

<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \times \pi \times 4^2 \times 9 \)</Incorrect Answer>

The base of the rectangle is 10m, and its height is 8m. The triangular section shares the same base as the rectangle and has a height of 6m. The triangle is indicated as the shaded area.</Question>

MisconceptionName: Believes mean is total divided by number of groups
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate the mean from a frequency table </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Averages and Range from Frequency Table </Subject Name>

<Question>The table below shows the number of books read by \( 15 \) students. Calculate the mean number of books read per student. 

\[
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of Books & Frequency \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\] 

</Question>

<Correct Answer>The mean number of books read per student is 

\[ \frac{(1 \times 2) + (2 \times 4) + (3 \times 3) + (4 \times 5) + (5 \times 1)}{2 + 4 + 3 + 5 + 1} = \frac{40}{15} \approx 2.67 \] 

</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The incorrect mean calculated by dividing the total by the number of groups is 

\[ \frac{(1 \times 2) + (2 \times 4) + (3 \times 3) + (4 \times 5) + (5 \times 1)}{5} = \frac{40}{5} = 8 \] 

</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes an interior angle in a regular polygon can be found using 180(n+2)/n
response:
<Construct Name>Determine the measure of each interior angle in a regular polygon </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Polygon Angle Properties </Subject Name>
<Question>Emily claims that you can find the measure of each interior angle in a regular decagon (10-sided polygon) by using the formula \(\frac{180(10+2)}{10}\). What is the correct interior angle measure of a regular decagon and what mistake does Emily make? </Question>
<Correct Answer>The correct measure of each interior angle in a regular decagon is \(144\) degrees. The correct formula is \(\frac{180(n-2)}{n}\), which gives \(\frac{180(10-2)}{10} = \frac{1440}{10} = 144\) degrees. </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>Using Emily's formula, \(\frac{180(10+2)}{10} = \frac{2160}{10} = 216\) degrees, which is incorrect because Emily mistakenly adds instead of subtracts 2 from the number of sides. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks that the perimeter on a square grid is the number of squares inside that are touching the perimeter of the shape
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate the Perimeter of a Shape on a Grid</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Perimeter Measurement</Subject Name>  
<Question>Consider a rectangle formed on a square grid that is 4 squares wide and 3 squares tall. What is the perimeter of this rectangle?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>14 units</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>10 units (counting only squares touching the perimeter)</Incorrect Answer>  

Explanation: The correct way to calculate the perimeter of a rectangle is by adding twice the width and twice the height, \(2 \times 4 + 2 \times 3 = 14\) units. The misconception arises when students mistakenly count the number of grid squares touching the perimeter, which totals 10 squares in this scenario.

MisconceptionName: Believes -a is always smaller than a, ignoring the possibility that a is negative
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding inequalities involving variables and their opposites </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Algebraic Inequalities </Subject Name>

<Question>Consider the inequality: \( x > -x \). Determine if this statement is true for all real numbers \( x \). </Question>

<Correct Answer>The statement is not true for all real numbers. It is true only when \( x > 0 \). For negative numbers, \( x < -x \). </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The statement is true for all real numbers because \(-x\) is always less than \( x \). </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When drawing a cumulative frequency diagram, thinks you plot cumulative frequency on the horizontal axis
response:
<Construct Name>Draw and interpret cumulative frequency diagrams</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Statistics</Subject Name>  
<Question>For a class test, the marks of students are as follows (grouped data): 10-20 (5 students), 20-30 (8 students), 30-40 (12 students), 40-50 (10 students), 50-60 (5 students). Draw a cumulative frequency diagram for this data.</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The cumulative frequency should be plotted on the vertical axis, and the upper boundary of each class interval on the horizontal axis. The cumulative frequencies to be plotted are: 10-20 (5), 20-30 (13), 30-40 (25), 40-50 (35), 50-60 (40).</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The cumulative frequency is plotted on the horizontal axis instead. Students might plot: 5 (10-20), 13 (20-30), 25 (30-40), 35 (40-50), 40 (50-60) with cumulative frequency on the x-axis, leading to an incorrect graph.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks millimetres and centimetres are the same
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Metric Units: Millimeters and Centimeters</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Measurement and Conversion</Subject Name>  
<Question>A string is 120 millimeters (mm) long. If another string is 12 centimeters (cm) long, which string is longer?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The 12-centimeter string</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Both strings are the same length</Incorrect Answer>  

In this problem, students with the misconception that millimeters and centimeters are the same might incorrectly conclude that 120 mm equals 120 cm, mistakenly equating the lengths and providing the incorrect answer. The correct approach involves understanding that 1 centimeter equals 10 millimeters, thus 12 cm equals 120 mm, showing the strings are the same length.

MisconceptionName: When factorising, believes they can choose different factors for each term
response:
<Construct Name>Identifying common factors in polynomials</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Factorization</Subject Name>

<Question>Factor the expression \( 12x^2 + 18x \).</Question>

<Correct Answer>To factor this expression correctly, first identify the greatest common factor (GCF) of the terms. The GCF of \( 12x^2 \) and \( 18x \) is \( 6x \). 
Thus, the expression can be factored as \( 6x(2x + 3) \).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The misconception may lead to someone choosing different factors for each term. For example,  a student might factor each term individually as \( 6x^2 + 9x \), extracting a unique factor from each term rather than a common factor.</Incorrect Answer>

<Correct Answer>Team B</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Team A</Incorrect Answer>

<Correct Answer>Each has the same amount consumed.</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Dark bar</Incorrect Answer>

<Construct Name>Selecting Proper Common Denominators</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Addition and Comparison of Fractions</Subject Name>

<Correct Answer>Vegetables</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Fruits</Incorrect Answer>

response:

<Question> $$\(( 3 + 2 \frac{3}{4} )\) Convert the sum to an improper fraction$$ </Question> 

<Correct Answer> $$\(\frac{23}{4}\)$$ </Correct Answer>

MisconceptionName: Confuses the factorised form of repeated roots and the difference of 2 squares
response:
<Construct Name>Solving Quadratic Equations with Repeated Roots</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Repeated Roots in Quadratic Equations</Subject Name>

<Question>Solve the equation \( x^2 - 6x + 9 = 0 \).</Question>

<Correct Answer>The correct factorisation of \( x^2 - 6x + 9 = 0 \) is \( (x-3)(x-3) = (x-3)^2 = 0 \). Therefore, the solution is \( x = 3 \) with a repeated root.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The student might incorrectly factorise using the difference of squares: \( (x-3)(x+3) = 0 \). This would incorrectly suggest the solutions \( x = 3 \) and \( x = -3 \), which are incorrect for this problem.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When multiplying algebraic terms written in the same base, adds the base variables and multiplies the powers.
response:
<Construct Name>Multiplying algebraic expressions</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Exponents and Powers</Subject Name>
<Question>Simplify the expression: \( x^3 \cdot x^4 \)</Question>
<Correct Answer>\( x^7 \)</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( x^1 \cdot 12 \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Only uses two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding and Deriving Sequence Rules</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Sequences and Series</Subject Name>

<Question>Consider the sequence: 3, 5, 7, 9, ... What is the term-to-term rule for this sequence?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The correct term-to-term rule is: Add 2 to the previous term to find the next term. This sequence is an arithmetic sequence with a common difference of 2.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The term-to-term rule based only on the first two terms is: Add 2 to the first term (3) to get the second term (5), but without verifying that this rule applies for subsequent terms, a student might incorrectly assume that you need to, for example, multiply by 1.67 (from 3 to 5 is approximately 1.67 times) instead of correctly identifying the addition pattern.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not divide to get a unitary amount before scaling up
response:
<Construct Name>Using unit rates to solve proportional reasoning problems</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Proportional Reasoning</Subject Name>  
<Question>If 3 notebooks cost $18, how much would 7 notebooks cost?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>To find the cost of 7 notebooks, first calculate the cost of one notebook by dividing $18 by 3, which gives $6 per notebook. Then, multiply $6 by 7 to get $42.</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The student might multiply the cost of 3 notebooks directly by 7, thinking it is a straightforward scaling up, which gives them $126.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Confuses cubic and quadratic graphs
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding the differences between quadratic and cubic functions </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Graph Interpretation and Identification </Subject Name>

<Question>Given the equation \(y = x^3 - 3x\), identify the type of graph it will produce.</Question>

<Correct Answer>The graph is a cubic graph characterized by having a point of inflection, and it changes direction twice as it moves through the origin from the bottom left to the top right.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The graph is a quadratic graph, forming a simple U or inverted U shape due to confusing the cubic function with a parabolic structure.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Has found the area of a triangle rather than an area of a parallelogram
response:
<Construct Name>Calculating the area of composite shapes involving triangles and parallelograms</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Area of Composite Shapes</Subject Name>

<Question>A piece of artwork includes a composite shape made by joining a triangle and a parallelogram. If the parallelogram has a base of \(8 \mathrm{~cm}\) and a height of \(5 \mathrm{~cm}\), and the triangle has the same base of \(8 \mathrm{~cm}\) and a height of \(5 \mathrm{~cm}\), what is the total area of the shape?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The area of the parallelogram is \(40 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\) and the area of the triangle is \(20 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\), so the total area is \(60 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Using the formula for the area of a triangle for both parts, the student concludes the total area is \(20 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} + 20 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} = 40 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: In the middle of the total column or row of a two way table, adds the other totals (including overall total), rather than finding the difference
response:
<Construct Name>Using Two-Way Tables to Summarize Data</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Data Handling</Subject Name>  
<Question>Consider a two-way table that summarizes the favorite fruits of 200 people. The total number of people who chose apples or bananas is 180. If out of these, 100 people chose apples, how many people chose bananas?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 80 \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 280 \) </Incorrect Answer>  

In this problem, the student should subtract the number of people who chose apples from the total number of people who chose apples or bananas to find out how many chose bananas. However, due to the misconception, they incorrectly add these numbers instead.

MisconceptionName: When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit
response:
<Construct Name>Subtract decimals with similar and different decimal places</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject Name>
<Question>\( 15.06 - 0.7 = \)</Question>
<Correct Answer>\( 14.36 \)</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( 15.36 \)</Incorrect Answer>

Misconception: Students might forget to adjust the whole number part when borrowing, leading to a mistake in subtracting one from the preceding digit (the ones place in this instance).

MisconceptionName: When calculating missing side length from perimeter, gives the total missing length instead of dividing for one side.
response:
<Construct Name>Find missing side length from perimeter of a polygon </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometry </Subject Name>  
<Question>A rectangle has a perimeter of 30 cm. If one pair of opposite sides is 8 cm each, what is the length of each side of the other pair? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>Calculate the total length of known sides: \(8 + 8 = 16\). Then subtract from the perimeter: \(30 - 16 = 14\). Divide the remaining length by 2 to find each side of the other pair: \(14 \div 2 = 7\). The length of each side of the other pair is 7 cm. </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Calculate the total length of known sides: \(8 + 8 = 16\). Then subtract from the perimeter: \(30 - 16 = 14\). The incorrect answer is 14 cm, assuming this is the length of one side. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not know the meaning of vertically opposite
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Vertically Opposite Angles</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometry</Subject Name>  
<Question>In the diagram below, two lines intersect at a point. If angle \( AOC \) measures \( 50^\circ \), what is the measure of angle \( BOD \)?  
\[
\angle AOC = 50^\circ
\]
\]  
Find \(\angle BOD\).  
\] </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\(\angle BOD = 50^\circ\) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\(\angle BOD = 130^\circ\) </Incorrect Answer>  

Explanation:  
Students might misconceive vertically opposite angles, thinking they refer to angles that literally appear above or below each other, or they might get confused with supplementary angles and subtract from \(180^\circ\). In this context, understanding that vertically opposite angles are equal when two lines intersect is crucial, hence angle \( BOD \) is indeed \( 50^\circ \).

MisconceptionName: Believes switching the x and y variables in a linear equation gives a perpendicular line
response:
<Construct Name>Finding the equation of lines perpendicular to a given line</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Analytic Geometry</Subject Name>  
<Question>Given the line with equation \( y = -3x + 4 \), determine the equation of a line that is perpendicular to it and passes through the point (0, 2).</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The slope of the perpendicular line is \(\frac{1}{3}\). Using the point-slope form, the equation is \( y = \frac{1}{3}x + 2 \).</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The line is perpendicular when we switch \( x \) and \( y \), giving \( x = -3y + 4 \), then solve for \( y \) to get \( y = -\frac{1}{3}x + \frac{4}{3} \) and modify for the point, resulting in \( y = -\frac{1}{3}x + 2 \), which is incorrect logic.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Adds instead of subtracts when using an area model for multiplication
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding subtraction in the context of partitioned rectangles</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Multiplicative reasoning in geometry</Subject Name>

<Question>A rectangle is divided into three regions by two vertical lines, forming two unshaded regions and a shaded one. The total width of the rectangle is 30 cm, and the height is 12 cm. The width of the rightmost unshaded region is 8 cm, and the width of the leftmost unshaded region is 10 cm. Calculate the area of the shaded region.</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 12 \times (30 - 10 - 8) = 12 \times 12 = 144 \text{ cm}^2 \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 12 \times (30 + 10 + 8) = 12 \times 48 = 576 \text{ cm}^2 \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives a different term, which is not the next
response:
<Construct Name>$$Identify and extend non-linear patterns by generalizing sequential positions in the pattern$$</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>$$Sequences-Others$$</Subject Name>  
<Question>$$Given the sequence where the 1st term is 1, the 2nd term is 4, the 3rd term is 9, and the 4th term is 16, determine what the 8th term in the sequence is.$$</Question>  
<Correct Answer>$$The 8th term in the sequence is 64, as the sequence follows the pattern of n^2 (where n is the term position), so the 8th term is 8^2 = 64.$$</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>$$The 5th term in the sequence is 25, as students might mistakenly choose the next term after the 4th (instead of calculating the 8th term), which is 5^2 = 25.$$</Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name>$$Analyze a geometric sequence to find a specific term distant from given examples$$</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>$$Sequences-Geometric$$</Subject Name>  
<Question>$$Given a geometric sequence where the first term is 2, the second term is 6, and the third term is 18, find the 6th term in the sequence.$$</Question>  
<Correct Answer>$$The 6th term in the sequence is 486, calculated by using the formula for the nth term of a geometric sequence: a_n = ar^{(n-1)}, where a = 2 and r = 3. Therefore, a_6 = 2*3^5 = 486.$$</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>$$The 4th term in the sequence is 54, as students may mistakenly calculate the next sequential term instead of the 6th term, leading to an answer of 18*3 = 54.$$</Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name>$$Predict terms in a sequence based on alternate patterns seen in every nth term$$</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>$$Sequences-Patterns$$</Subject Name>  
<Question>$$Consider a sequence derived from two alternating patterns: the 1st, 3rd, and 5th terms follow an arithmetic sequence with a difference of 2, starting from 1. The 2nd, 4th, and 6th terms follow an arithmetic sequence with a difference of 3, starting from 2. What is the value of the 7th term in the sequence?$$</Question>  
<Correct Answer>$$The 7th term is 13, following the arithmetic sequence (1, 3, 5, 7…). Continuing the pattern from where 5 leaves off, the sequence yields 1, 2, 3, 5, 5, 8, 7, resulting in the 7th term going back to the first sequence with 7 + 2 = 13.$$</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>$$The 5th term is 9, resulting from a student’s confusion about which sequence to apply to find the 7th term, leading to calculations continuing from the 6th term: 8 + 1 = 9.$$</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Uses the other part instead of total frequency as denominator for relative frequency
response:
<Construct Name>Calculating relative frequency from a frequency table, distinguishing between different categories</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Statistics - Frequency and Relative Frequency</Subject Name>

<Question>Given the following frequency table, calculate the relative frequency of Group A:

| Group | Frequency |
|-------|-----------|
| A     | 10        |
| B     | 15        |
| C     | 5         |

</Question>

<Correct Answer>The correct relative frequency of Group A is calculated by dividing the frequency of Group A by the total frequency: 
\( \frac{10}{10+15+5} = \frac{10}{30} = \frac{1}{3} \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The incorrect relative frequency from this misunderstanding would be:
\( \frac{10}{15} \)
Students mistakenly use the frequency of the other group (Group B) as the denominator.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Removes the common denominator when making equivalent algebraic fractions
response:
<Construct Name>Working with rational expressions involving quadratic expressions in the denominator</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions with Quadratic Denominators</Subject Name>

<Question>Simplify the expression and express it as a single fraction:
\(
\frac{x+4}{x^2-1} - \frac{2x-3}{x^2-1}
\)</Question>

<Correct Answer>\(\frac{x + 4 - (2x - 3)}{x^2 - 1} = \frac{-x + 7}{x^2 - 1}\)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\((x+4) - (2x-3) = -x + 7\)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Rounds a decimal instead of using a fraction in division
response:
<Construct Name>Use of Decimals in Division</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Fraction and Decimal Calculations</Subject Name>  
<Question>Divide 5.6 by 0.8 and express the answer as a fraction in simplest form.</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( \frac{7}{1} \) or simply \( 7 \)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{8}{1} \) or \( 8 \)</Incorrect Answer>  

Explanation:  
The correct approach is to convert the division of decimals into fractions:  
\[
\frac{5.6}{0.8} = \frac{56}{8} = \frac{7}{1} = 7
\]  
However, a common mistake is to round the decimals first and then perform the division, leading to:
\[
\frac{6}{1} = 8
\]
Students might think of 5.6 as approximately 6 and 0.8 as approximately 1, resulting in the erroneous answer of 8.

MisconceptionName: Does not recognise feet (ft) as a unit of length
response:
<Construct Name>Unit Conversion and Measurement Recognition</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry and Measurement</Subject Name>

<Question>A rectangular garden has a length of \( 20 \) yards and a width of \( 15 \) yards. The gardener wants to lay a fence around the perimeter of the garden. He needs to find the total length of the fence in feet. What is the total length of the fence?</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 210 \text{ feet} \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 70 \text{ feet} \) </Incorrect Answer>

Explanation:
The perimeter of the rectangle is calculated by using the formula \( 2 \times (\text{length} + \text{width}) \). In this case, it should be \( 2 \times (20 \text{ yards} + 15 \text{ yards}) = 70 \text{ yards} \). To convert yards to feet, multiply by 3 (since 1 yard = 3 feet). Hence, the correct perimeter in feet is \( 70 \times 3 = 210 \text{ feet} \). The incorrect answer of 70 feet likely results from not recognizing the need to convert yards to feet.

MisconceptionName: Does not know that angles on a straight line sum to 180 degrees
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate unknown angles in a linear pair </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometry - Angles and Lines </Subject Name>  
<Question>If angle \( x \) and angle \( y \) form a linear pair, and angle \( x \) is \( 120^{\circ} \), what is the measure of angle \( y \)? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 60^{\circ} \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 240^{\circ} \) </Incorrect Answer>  

Misconception: When students misunderstand that angles on a straight line (which form a linear pair) sum to 180 degrees, they might mistakenly think that the angles could sum to more or less than 180 degrees. In this problem, they may incorrectly assume that since one angle is \( 120^{\circ} \), the other angle must add up to something other than \( 60^{\circ} \), such as \( 240^{\circ} \), under the false assumption that angles on a straight line must surpass 180 degrees.

MisconceptionName: Believes they can reverse a percentage increase or decrease by dividing by the decimal multiplier of the original change
response:
<Construct Name>Reverse percentage calculations </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Percentage Calculations </Subject Name>
<Question>A jacket is on sale for 20% less than its original price and is now priced at £80. What was the original price of the jacket? </Question>
<Correct Answer>The original price was \( £100 \). To work this out, divide the sale price by 0.8 (since a 20% discount leaves 80% of the original price): \( \frac{£80}{0.8} = £100 \). </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The incorrect approach is to think the price can be reversed by dividing by the discount multiplier of 0.2, leading to: \( \frac{£80}{0.2} = £400 \), which is incorrect. </Incorrect Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( C = 55m + 30 \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks the sum of 2 numbers, each squared first, is the same as adding the two numbers and then squaring the total
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Expressions with Squares</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Algebraic Identities and Expressions</Subject Name>  
<Question>If \( a = 4 \) and \( b = 3 \), calculate \( a^2 + b^2 \).</Question>  
<Correct Answer>25 </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>49 </Incorrect Answer>  

The incorrect answer results from the misunderstanding that the student might have calculated \((a + b)^2\) instead of \(a^2 + b^2\), which would be \((4 + 3)^2 = 7^2 = 49\).

MisconceptionName: In ratio where total is given, treats that as one part without dividing
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Proportions in Ratio Problems</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Dividing Quantities by Ratios</Subject Name>

<Question>Jessica and Ryan received a total of \( 56 \) cookies to share in the ratio of \( 5 : 3 \). How many cookies does each person get?</Question>

<Correct Answer>Jessica gets \( 35 \) cookies and Ryan gets \( 21 \) cookies. First, add the parts of the ratio: \( 5 + 3 = 8 \). Then, divide the total number of cookies by the total parts to find the value of one part: \( 56 \div 8 = 7 \). Jessica gets \( 5 \) parts, so she receives \( 5 \times 7 = 35 \) cookies. Ryan gets \( 3 \) parts, so he receives \( 3 \times 7 = 21 \) cookies.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Jessica gets \( 280 \) cookies and Ryan gets \( 168 \) cookies. Incorrectly assuming the total of \( 56 \) is a single part, students might mistakenly calculate \( 5 \times 56 = 280 \) for Jessica and \( 3 \times 56 = 168 \) for Ryan.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Includes too many possibilites when given an 'at least' question in probability
response:
<Construct Name>Identify possible outcomes and probabilities when given non-specific events in probability problems</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Probability Theory</Subject Name>

<Question>An unbiased six-sided die is rolled. What is the probability of rolling at least a 4?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The outcomes that are at least 4 are 4, 5, and 6. So, the probability is \(\frac{3}{6} = \frac{1}{2}\).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>All the possible outcomes for rolling a die include 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. Assuming everything is covered, this gives a probability of 1.0 for any event.</Incorrect Answer>

<Question>Solve and graph the inequality \(3x - 5 < 4\) on a number line.</Question>

<Correct Answer>\(x < 3\); This means that any number less than 3 is a solution. The inequality represents a range of numbers. When graphed on a number line, it is shown as an open circle at 3 and shading to the left to indicate all numbers less than 3 are solutions.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\(x = 3\); The student may incorrectly believe there's a singular value solution to the inequality. They might incorrectly graph this misunderstanding as a closed circle at 3, erroneously indicating 3 as the sole solution.</Incorrect Answer>

<Question>Brian wants to find the distance between the two points, A(4, 3) and B(-2, -1). What is the correct method to find the distance between these points?</Question> 

<Correct Answer>\(\sqrt{(x_2 - x_1)^2 + (y_2 - y_1)^2}\), which leads to \(\sqrt{(-2 - 4)^2 + (-1 - 3)^2} = \sqrt{36 + 16} = \sqrt{52} = 2\sqrt{13}\)</Correct Answer> 

<Incorrect Answer>\(\left(\frac{x_1 + x_2}{2}, \frac{y_1 + y_2}{2}\right)\), which leads to \(\left(\frac{4 + (-2)}{2}, \frac{3 + (-1)}{2}\right) = \left(1, 1\right)\)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When using the capture-recapture method, confuses the order of the calculation to find best estimate of population
response:
<Construct Name>Capture-Recapture Method for Estimating Population Size</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Statistics and Probability</Subject Name>  
<Question>  
A wildlife researcher captures, tags, and releases 100 fish into a lake. After some time, she captures 50 fish and finds that 10 of them are tagged. Use the capture-recapture method to estimate the total population of fish in the lake.  
</Question>  
<Correct Answer>  
Using the formula: \( \frac{\text{Number of tagged fish in the second sample}}{\text{Size of the second sample}} = \frac{\text{Number of tagged fish}}{\text{Total population}} \), we have:

\(\frac{10}{50} = \frac{100}{N}\).

Solving for \(N\), we get \(N = 500\). So, the estimated total population of fish in the lake is 500.  
</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>  
Confusion leads to mistakenly using the wrong order or fraction in the calculation. A possible incorrect setup might be \(\frac{50}{10} = \frac{N}{100}\).

Solving for \(N\) here gives \(N = 5,000\), which is incorrect.  
</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes when you plot a linear sequence it doesn't give a straight line
response:
<Construct Name>Recognizing patterns in linear sequences </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Graphing Sequences and Functions </Subject Name>

<Question>Consider the linear sequence given by the rule \(a_n = 3n + 2\), where \(n\) represents the position in the sequence. Plot the sequence on a graph with \(n\) on the x-axis and \(a_n\) on the y-axis. Is the graph a straight line? </Question>

<Correct Answer>Yes, the graph is a straight line. When plotted, the points will lie on a line with a slope of 3 and a y-intercept of 2. The plotted points are (1, 5), (2, 8), (3, 11), and so on. </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>No, the graph does not form a straight line. The points do not lie on a single straight line. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes an outlier is a value that does not fit the same characteristics as the other values
response:
<Construct Name>$$INSERT TEXT HERE$$Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number$$</Construct Name>   
<Subject Name>$$INSERT TEXT HERE$$Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data$$</Subject Name>   
<Question>$$INSERT TEXT HERE$$\(\frac{3}{4}, \frac{9}{12}, \frac{2}{3}, 0.75, \frac{6}{10}, \frac{14}{18}\) Which value is the outlier in this set of data?$$</Question>   
<Correct Answer>$$INSERT TEXT HERE$$\(\frac{6}{10}\)$$</Correct Answer>   
<Incorrect Answer>$$INSERT TEXT HERE$$\(\frac{14}{18}\)$$</Incorrect Answer> 

Explanation:  
In the context of averages and data analysis, an outlier is a value that falls significantly outside the range of the other values in the set. It is not merely a value that appears different in format or structure, but a number that deviates numerically from the rest. When students identify a value like \(\frac{14}{18}\), they might do so because it seems visually different or doesn't match the fractions converted to decimals as neatly. However, \(\frac{6}{10}\), being numerically more distant from the cluster of values around 0.75, is the true outlier.

<Question> $$Consider the claim: "All quadratic functions have a maximum or minimum value." Identify a counter-example for this claim, or explain why it may be true.$$

<Correct Answer> $$The claim is true for all quadratic functions. Quadratic functions are always parabolic in shape, either opening upwards or downwards, which means they always have a vertex representing a minimum or maximum point.$$

MisconceptionName: Believes class width represents area of the bar in a histogram
response:
<Construct Name>Interpretation of the class width and its relationship to bar height in histograms</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Statistics</Subject Name>

<Question>A histogram displays the frequency distribution of student scores on a math test. The first class interval ranges from 0 to 10, the second from 10 to 20, and so forth up to 50. The height of the bar representing the class interval from 40 to 50 is twice that of the bar representing the class interval from 30 to 40. Given this information, what is the interpretation of the area of the bar for the class interval from 40 to 50 in relation to the class interval from 30 to 40?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The area of each bar represents the frequency within that class; hence, if the height of the bar from 40 to 50 is twice that of the 30 to 40 class, then the frequency for scores in the 40 to 50 class is twice that in the 30 to 40 class.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The class width for the interval from 40 to 50 is the same as the class width for 30 to 40, meaning the area of the bar represents the same frequency.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Rotates instead of reflects
response:
<Construct Name>Reflect an object across a diagonal line, such as \( y = x \) or \( y = -x \), where the reflection line is crossing through or near the object </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Reflection </Subject Name>

<Question>Consider a square with vertices at \( A(-3, -3) \), \( B(-3, 1) \), \( C(1, 1) \), and \( D(1, -3) \). Reflect the square across the line \( y = x \). What are the new coordinates of vertex \( A \)? </Question>

<Correct Answer>The correct coordinates for vertex \( A \) after the reflection are \( (-3, -3) \). However, since reflection over \( y = x \) is asked, the correct new position should be \( (-3, -3) \rightarrow (-3, -3) \) for symmetry (as a square will have such property at \( y=x \)). </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The student might incorrectly apply a 90-degree rotation transformation, giving the coordinates as \( A(-3, 3) \) expecting a similar transformation across the quadrants but miscalculating refraction as rotation. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the constant only gives the y-intercept for linear graphs
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding the Role of Constants in Quadratic Functions </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Analyzing Key Features of Quadratic and Linear Equations </Subject Name>

<Question>Consider the quadratic function \( f(x) = 2x^2 + 3x + 5 \). 

Sarah claims that the constant term 5 is the y-intercept of the function on its graph.

Calculate the true y-intercept of the function's graph and verify Sarah's statement.</Question> 

<Correct Answer>The y-intercept of the function is found by evaluating the function at \( x = 0 \). So, \( f(0) = 2(0)^2 + 3(0) + 5 = 5 \). Therefore, Sarah is correct; the constant term does give the y-value of the y-intercept in this quadratic function.</Correct Answer> 

<Incorrect Answer>Sarah's claim that the constant term 5 is the y-intercept is incorrect because the role of the constant term is not limited to giving the y-intercept in non-linear functions.</Incorrect Answer>

response:

<Correct Answer>$6</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>$4</Incorrect Answer>

In this case, a student might find an equivalent ratio by simply adding instead of multiplying. If 3 apples cost $2, the student incorrectly scales up by thinking 6 more apples might cost an additional $2 (from $2 to $4) instead of correctly multiplying the entire ratio by 3 (since 9 apples are 3 times 3 apples).

MisconceptionName: Believes all linear graphs show direct proportion
response:
<Construct Name>Identify direct proportion from linear graphs</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Linear Graphs and Proportionality</Subject Name>

<Question>Consider the linear graph given by the equation \( y = 3x + 2 \). Does this graph represent a direct proportion between \( x \) and \( y \)?</Question> 

<Correct Answer>No, this graph does not represent a direct proportion. A direct proportion graph passes through the origin, which requires the equation to be in the form \( y = kx \). This equation has a y-intercept of 2 and does not pass through the origin.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Yes, this graph represents a direct proportion because it is a linear equation.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Expands when asked to simplify
response:
<Construct Name>Addition of algebraic fractions with similar denominators </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions </Subject Name>
<Question>Simplify the following expression:
\[
\frac{x+2}{x+3} + \frac{2x+4}{x+3}
\] </Question> 
<Correct Answer>\( \frac{3x+6}{x+3} \) or further simplified to \(3 \) as the expression simplifies to \( \frac{3(x+2)}{x+3} \), and \( x+3 \) cancels with \( x+3 \). </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{x+2 + 2x+4}{x+3} = \frac{3x+6}{x^2+3x} \) </Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Division of algebraic fractions with polynomials </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions </Subject Name>
<Question>Divide and simplify:
\[
\frac{x^2 - 9}{x^2 + 3x} \div \frac{x-3}{x}
\] </Question> 
<Correct Answer>\( \frac{x(x+3)}{x} \) simplifies to \( x+3 \) after cancellation. </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{x^2-9}{x^2+3x} \times \frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{x^3 - 9x}{x^3+3x^2} \) </Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Complex number multiplication </Construct Name>

\[
(2+i)(1-i)
\] </Question> 
<Correct Answer>\( 3 - i \) </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( 2 - i^2 \) (students may incorrectly expand and not correctly use the fact that \( i^2 = -1 \)) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Forgets to subtract sum of angles we know from 180 to find missing angle in a triangle
response:
<Construct Name>Find missing angles in a right triangle</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry - Angles in a Triangle</Subject Name>

<Question>A right triangle has one angle of \( 35^{\circ} \). Calculate the size of the other non-right angle, \( x \). </Question>

<Correct Answer>The sum of angles in a triangle is \( 180^{\circ} \). Since it's a right triangle, one angle is \( 90^{\circ} \). 
\[ x = 180^{\circ} - 90^{\circ} - 35^{\circ} = 55^{\circ} \]</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 145^{\circ} \) (Obtained by adding 90 and 35, forgetting to subtract from 180)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Draws both angles at the same end of the line when constructing a triangle
response:
<Construct Name>Construct a triangle using two given angles and a side not in between (Angle-Angle-Side) </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Triangle Construction Using Angles </Subject Name>

<Question>How would you construct a triangle where one of the sides measures \( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \) and the angles adjacent to this side measure \( 30^{\degree} \) and \( 70^{\degree} \)? </Question> 

<Correct Answer>- Draw a line \( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \) long.
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 30^{\degree} \), and place a dot.
- Place a protractor at the opposite end of the line, measure \( 70^{\degree} \), and place a dot.
- Draw straight lines extending from each end of the \( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \) line through the respective dots.
- Where these lines intersect completes the triangle. </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>- Draw a line \( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \) long.
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 30^{\degree} \), and place a dot.
- Place the protractor back at the same end of the line, measure \( 70^{\degree} \), and place another dot.
- Draw straight lines from the end of the line through these same-dot positions.
- Assuming these lines will intersect at a point to complete the triangle (which they won't in this construction). </Incorrect Answer>

![A graph with a y-axis labeled 'Distance in miles' and marked with values 0, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60. The space between the origin and the first mark (0 to 10) is half the distance of other marks; the remaining marks are equally spaced.]() 
</Question>

MisconceptionName: Believes a rotation and a reflection can be combined by applying the rotation to the mirror line
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding transformations and their compositions</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometry and Transformations</Subject Name>  
<Question>A triangle is reflected over the line \(y = x\) and then rotated \(90^\circ\) clockwise about the origin. What is the final position of the triangle?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The triangle is first reflected over the line \(y = x\) and then rotated \(90^\circ\) clockwise about the origin, resulting in swapping the coordinates and then rotating them, which changes the sign of the y-coordinates. Thus, if the original triangle has vertices \(A(x_1, y_1)\), \(B(x_2, y_2)\), and \(C(x_3, y_3)\), the final coordinates would be \(A'(y_1, -x_1)\), \(B'(y_2, -x_2)\), and \(C'(y_3, -x_3)\).</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Students might incorrectly apply the rotation to the mirror line itself, rather than the triangle, leading them to believe that the final reflection is over a line rotated \(90^\circ\) clockwise. This would lead them incorrectly to think that the mirror line changes and there are no additional rotations to apply after that, essentially leaving some versions of the triangle at \(A'(y_1, x_1)\), \(B'(y_2, x_2)\), and \(C'(y_3, x_3)\).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the median is the category with the median frequency
response:
<Construct Name>Finding the median in a frequency distribution</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Statistics and Probability</Subject Name>

<Question>A survey of the number of books owned by students in a class is conducted, and the frequency distribution is as follows:

- 0-2 books: 3 students
- 3-5 books: 7 students
- 6-8 books: 12 students
- 9-11 books: 5 students
- 12-14 books: 3 students

Find the median number of books owned by the students.</Question>

<Correct Answer>The median class is 6-8 books. The median falls within this class as the cumulative frequency just exceeds half the total frequency (15). Specifically, the median number of books owned is computed through interpolation within this class.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The median is 6-8 books because 12 students fall in this category, which is the median frequency.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When drawing a cumulative frequency diagram, thinks you plot the upper bound of the class intervals on the vertical axis
response:
<Construct Name>Plotting cumulative frequency graphs </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Data handling and statistics </Subject Name>

<Question>The frequency distribution table below shows the ages of participants in a survey:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Age (years)} & \text{Frequency} \\
\hline
10 - 14 & 5 \\
15 - 19 & 8 \\
20 - 24 & 12 \\
25 - 29 & 9 \\
30 - 34 & 6 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

Use the data to draw a cumulative frequency diagram. </Question>

<Correct Answer>1. Compute the cumulative frequency for each class:

- \(10 - 14\): 5 
- \(15 - 19\): 5 + 8 = 13 
- \(20 - 24\): 13 + 12 = 25 
- \(25 - 29\): 25 + 9 = 34 
- \(30 - 34\): 34 + 6 = 40 

2. Plot the cumulative frequencies on the vertical axis using the upper class boundary on the horizontal axis (not the upper bound of the frequency). The points would be plotted as follows:
   
- Plot the point at 14 with a cumulative frequency of 5.
- Plot the point at 19 with a cumulative frequency of 13.
- Plot the point at 24 with a cumulative frequency of 25.
- Plot the point at 29 with a cumulative frequency of 34.
- Plot the point at 34 with a cumulative frequency of 40.

3. Connect the points with a smooth curve to form the cumulative frequency diagram. </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>1. Compute the cumulative frequency for each class:

- \(10 - 14\): 5 
- \(15 - 19\): 5 + 8 = 13 
- \(20 - 24\): 13 + 12 = 25 
- \(25 - 29\): 25 + 9 = 34 
- \(30 - 34\): 34 + 6 = 40 

2. Incorrectly plot the upper class limit on the vertical axis by placing values such as 14, 19, 24, 29, and 34 on the vertical axis, which is incorrect.

3. The plot incorrectly marks these points on the graph and joins them, leading to an incorrect cumulative frequency diagram. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Mistakes rotations for translations
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Rotations on a Coordinate Plane</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry - Rotations</Subject Name>

<Question>Consider the point \( P(3, 4) \). Rotate the point 90 degrees counterclockwise about the origin. What should be the new coordinates of point \( P \), and what error might a student make by confusing rotation with translation?</Question>

<Correct Answer>After rotating point \( P(3, 4) \) 90 degrees counterclockwise about the origin, the new coordinates should be \( P'(-4, 3) \). This is achieved by the transformation \( (x, y) \rightarrow (-y, x) \).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>By mistaking rotation for translation, a student might translate the point instead, incorrectly assuming \( P \) moves by the vector \( (0, -4) \), resulting in the incorrect coordinates \( P'(3, 0) \).</Incorrect Answer>

<Correct Answer>3.68</Correct Answer>

MisconceptionName: Assumes they multiply by the numerator of fractional index
response:
<Construct Name>Raise an integer to a positive non-unit fraction power </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Laws of Indices </Subject Name>  
<Question>\( (8)^{\frac{3}{2}}=? \) </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 16 \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 12 \) </Incorrect Answer>  

Misconception: Students might multiply the base directly by the numerator. In this case, instead of correctly understanding that \( (8)^{\frac{3}{2}} \) should be tackled as two operations (finding the square root of 8, followed by cubing the result or vice versa), they incorrectly compute \( 8 \times 3 = 24 \) and take the square root of 24, then might round it down to 12. The correct method involves \((8^{1/2})^3 = (2 \sqrt{2})^3 = 16\) after simplification.

<Construct Name>Identify the next term in a Fibonacci sequence </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Sequences and Series </Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the next term in the Fibonacci sequence?  
\[
1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, \ldots
\] </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 13 \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 9 \) </Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name>Predict the next term in a geometric sequence </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometric Sequences </Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the next term in this geometric sequence?  
\[
2, 6, 18, 54, \ldots
\] </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 162 \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 55 \) </Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name>Find the next term in an arithmetic sequence with fractions </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Arithmetic Sequences </Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the next term in this fractional sequence?  
\[
\frac{1}{2}, \frac{2}{3}, \frac{5}{6}, \frac{4}{3}, \ldots
\] </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( \frac{7}{6} \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{5}{3} \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Confuses a formula with an equation

<Incorrect Answer>Equation </Incorrect Answer>

<Correct Answer>Equation </Correct Answer>

<Correct Answer>Formula </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Equation </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the mean is the middle number
response:

MisconceptionName: Believes that rounding parts of a fraction in different directions means the answer will be the same.
response:
<Construct Name>Estimating Calculations Involving Fractions by Rounding Numerator and Denominator Independently</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Estimation and Rounding</Subject Name>
<Question>Estimate the value of the fraction \(\frac{672}{345}\) by rounding to the nearest hundred.</Question> 
<Correct Answer>By rounding, \(\frac{672}{345} \approx \frac{700}{300} = \frac{7}{3} \approx 2.33\)</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>Rounding the numerator and denominator separately to nearest hundred: \(\frac{700}{300} = \frac{7}{3} \approx 2.33\)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise
response:
<Construct Name>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a) </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Factorising into a Single Bracket </Subject Name>

<Question>Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
x^{2}+6x
\) </Question>

<Correct Answer>\( x(x+6) \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( (x+3)(x+3) \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When dividing by a non unit fraction, thinks you multiply by the reciprocal of the corresponding unit fraction rather than the fraction given.
response:
<Construct Name>Dividing Fractions by Fractions </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Dividing Fractions </Subject Name>

<Question>If \( \frac{2}{3} \) of a bottle of juice is shared equally among \( \frac{4}{5} \) of a person, how much juice does each person get? </Question>

<Correct Answer>\( \frac{10}{12} \) or simplified to \( \frac{5}{6} \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{15}{8} \) or simplified to \( \frac{1\frac{7}{8}} \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not understand the place value of answers from a Napier's bones calculation
response:
<Construct Name>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using Napier’s bones </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Written Multiplication </Subject Name>
<Question>Dave is trying to solve this problem using Napier's bones
What number does the circled digit represent? \( 714 \times 85 \) ![A Napier's bones grid, with 714 along the top and 85 down the side. From left to right on the top row, with / representing a diagonal line through the box, the boxes read 5/6, 8/5, 7/2. From left to right on the bottom row, the boxes read 3/5, 4/2, 3/5. The digit 6 is circled in the first box of the top row, under the 7 of 714 and the 8 of 85.]() </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 600 \)</Correct Answer> 
<Incorrect Answer>\( 6 \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not subtract 2 from the number of sides when finding the sum of interior angles
response:
<Construct Name>Finding the sum of the interior angles of a polygon</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Geometry and Polygons</Subject Name>
<Question>Calculate the sum of the interior angles of a hexagon.</Question>
<Correct Answer>The sum of the interior angles of a hexagon is calculated using the formula \((n-2) \times 180\). For a hexagon, \(n=6\), so \((6-2) \times 180 = 720\) degrees.</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The sum of the interior angles of a hexagon is calculated as \(n \times 180\) without subtracting 2. So, it is \(6 \times 180 = 1080\) degrees.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Confuses the calculations for HCF and LCM
response:
<Construct Name>Use prime factor decomposition to find the Highest Common Factor of two numbers</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject Name>  
<Question>  
Find the highest common factor (HCF) of \( 48 \) and \( 180 \) using the prime factor decomposition method.  
\[ 48 = 2^4 \times 3 \]  
\[ 180 = 2^2 \times 3^2 \times 5 \]  
What is the highest common factor of these two numbers?  
</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 2^2 \times 3 = 12 \)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 2^4 \times 3^2 \times 5 = 720 \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes when simplifying a fraction you can divide the numerator and denominator by different values
response:
<Construct Name>Multiply fractions and whole numbers to simplify </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Multiplying Fractions </Subject Name>  
<Question>Multiply and simplify:  
\[  
4 \times \frac{6}{8}  
\]  
</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( \frac{3}{1} \) or simply \( 3 \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{3}{2} \) </Incorrect Answer>  

Misconception: Often, students incorrectly divide the numerator by 2 and the denominator by 4, leading to the incorrect simplification. The correct approach involves first multiplying the fraction by the whole number and appropriately simplifying by dividing both the numerator and the denominator by their greatest common divisor.

<Correct Answer>\( a_5 = 2(5) + 1 = 11 \)</Correct Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not know how to check tessellation
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Tessellation and Patterns</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometry</Subject Name>  
<Question>Determine whether a regular hexagon tessellates in the plane without gaps or overlaps. Provide a brief explanation for your answer.</Question>  
<Correct Answer>Yes, a regular hexagon tessellates because the interior angles (120 degrees) of regular hexagons add up to 360 degrees at a point (3 hexagons meet), filling the plane without gaps or overlaps.</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>No, a regular hexagon does not tessellate because it does not have right angles, which are necessary for tessellation.</Incorrect Answer>

<Question>An item costs $25 and the sales tax is 8%. Calculate the total price. </Question>

<Correct Answer>The total price is \$25 \times \frac{108}{100} = \$27. </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The total price is \$25 \div \frac{100}{108} = \$0.27. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes splitting a multiplication using the distributive property is the same as splitting it into factors
response:
<Construct Name>Recognise and apply the distributive property of multiplication over addition</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Pre-Algebra and Arithmetic</Subject Name>

<Question>Simplify the expression using the distributive property: \( 8 \times 13 \).</Question>

<Correct Answer>The correct simplification using the distributive property is: \( 8 \times 13 = 8 \times (10 + 3) = 8 \times 10 + 8 \times 3 = 80 + 24 = 104 \).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Splitting the multiplication into factors incorrectly might look like: \( 8 \times 13 = 4 \times 2 \times 13 = 4 \times (2 \times 13) = 4 \times 26 = 104 \).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes inequalities can only include integers
response:
<Construct Name>Linear Inequality Word Problems </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Solving Word Problems Involving Inequalities </Subject Name>
<Question>Alice has more than $25 in her wallet. If she has \( 2.5x \) dollars and each unit of \( x \) is worth $10, write an inequality for \( x \) and solve it. </Question> 
<Correct Answer>The inequality is \( 2.5x > 2.5 \). Solving gives \( x > 1 \). Thus, \( x \) is greater than 1, meaning that Alice has more than 1 unit, so more than $10. </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The inequality is \( 2.5x > 2.5 \). Solving gives \( x > 2 \). This would mean Alice has more than 2 units, so more than $20, but that's incorrect because it assumes \( x \) only takes integer values. </Incorrect Answer>

<Construct Name>Graphing Linear Inequalities in Two Variables </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Graphing Inequalities </Subject Name>
<Question>Graph the inequality \( y < 2.5x + 1 \) on the coordinate plane. </Question> 
<Correct Answer>To graph \( y < 2.5x + 1 \), draw a dashed line for \( y = 2.5x + 1 \) and shade the region below the line, as it represents \( y \) values that are less than \( 2.5x + 1 \). </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>To graph \( y < 2.5x + 1 \), some students might mistakenly draw a dashed line for \( y = 3x + 1 \) and only shade integer points below the line, assuming \( x \) and \( y \) are integers. </Incorrect Answer>

<Question>What is the measure of angle \(\angle ABC\) if line \(AB\) is aligned with 0/180 degrees and line \(BC\) points from the center to between 120/60 and 130/50 on a protractor rotated such that 0 is at the top?</Question>
<Correct Answer>\( 125^{\circ} \)</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( 0^{\circ} \)</Incorrect Answer>

response:
