MisconceptionName: When finding the area of a parallelogram does not understand which lengths to use
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Dimensions of a Parallelogram for Area Calculation</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometry: Area of Parallelograms</Subject Name>  
<Question>Consider a parallelogram where one side is 12 inches, the slanted side is 7 inches, and the perpendicular height from the base (forming a right angle with the base) is 5 inches. Calculate the area of the parallelogram.</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 60 \mathrm{~in}^{2} \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 84 \mathrm{~in}^{2} \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes a number raised to a power will always give a positive answer
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding powers and exponents </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Algebra </Subject Name>  
<Question>Consider the expression \((-3)^n\). For which of the following values of \(n\) is the expression negative?  
a) \(n = 2\)  
b) \(n = 3\)  
c) \(n = 4\)  
d) \(n = 5\)  
</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The expression is negative for \(n = 3\) and \(n = 5\), which are odd integers. </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>None of the above; the belief is that \((-3)^n\) will always give a positive answer for any \(n\). </Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name>Understanding sign changes in multiplication </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Pre-Algebra </Subject Name>  
<Question>Which of the following expressions results in a negative number:  
a) \((-2)^3\)  
b) \((-2)^4\)  
c) \((-2)^5\)  
d) \((-2)^6\)  
</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The expressions \((-2)^3\) and \((-2)^5\) result in negative numbers because raising a negative number to an odd power results in a negative number. </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>None of the above; the belief may be that \((-2)^n\) always results in a positive answer regardless of whether \(n\) is even or odd. </Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name>Evaluation of expressions with integers </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Number Theory </Subject Name>  
<Question>Evaluate the expression \((-4)^n\) when \(n = 7\). Does it result in a positive or negative number? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>The expression \((-4)^7\) results in a negative number because raising a negative integer to an odd power results in a negative integer. </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The expression is incorrectly thought to be positive, due to the misconception that raising to any power will negate the negative sign. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes multiplying together prime factors that are not shared gives the highest common factor
response:
<Construct Name>Finding the Highest Common Factor (HCF) of two numbers using prime factorization</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Number Theory</Subject Name>

<Question>Find the highest common factor (HCF) of 36 and 60 using their prime factorizations.</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 12 \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 180 \) </Incorrect Answer>

Explanation: Students often get confused when finding the highest common factor by multiplying the prime factors that are not supposed to be included in the HCF. Instead of multiplying only the common prime factors, they mistakenly multiply both the uncommon prime factors. In the given problem, the prime factorization of 36 is \( 2^2 \times 3^2 \), and for 60, it is \( 2^2 \times 3 \times 5 \). The common prime factors are \( 2^2 \) and \( 3 \), hence the HCF is \( 2^2 \times 3 = 12 \). However, a student might incorrectly multiply all the prime factors together, leading to an answer of \((2 \times 3^2 \times 5) = 180\).

MisconceptionName: Only counts visible vertices
response:
<Construct Name>$$Identifying and Counting Vertices, Edges, and Faces of 3D Shapes$$</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>$$Geometry - Properties of Three-Dimensional Figures$$</Subject Name>
<Question>$$How many vertices does this pyramid have?$$</Question>
<Correct Answer>$$5$$</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>$$4$$</Incorrect Answer>

Explanation: In this scenario, students may see only the visible base vertices and the apex from a certain perspective, missing one additional vertex hidden behind the shape.

MisconceptionName: Does not include brackets when attempting to multiply an expression
response:
<Construct Name>Evaluate algebraic expressions with multiple operations</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Algebraic Expressions</Subject Name>

<Question>A rectangle has a length that is 3 units more than twice the width. If the width is represented by \( w \), write an expression for the perimeter of the rectangle.</Question>

<Correct Answer>The correct expression is \( 2(2w + 3) + 2w \) or simplified, \( 6w + 6 \).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The incorrect expression resulting from not using brackets is \( 2 \cdot 2w + 3 + 2w \), which simplifies incorrectly to \( 6w + 3 \).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks angles can only be measured when one line is horizontal
response:
<Construct Name>Identifying Types of Angles</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometry</Subject Name>  
<Question>Determine the measure of angle \( \angle A \) in the image, where two lines intersect at point A, without either line being horizontal.</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( \angle A = 120^{\circ} \) (or another appropriate measurement based on the diagram provided)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>This is not an angle</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes that we cannot calculate the mean of negative numbers
response:
<Construct Name>Calculating the Mean of Integers</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Statistics</Subject Name>
<Question>What is the mean of the following set of numbers: \(-5, -10, -15, -20\)? </Question>
<Correct Answer>The mean is \(-12.5\), which is calculated by adding the numbers: \(-5 + (-10) + (-15) + (-20) = -50\) and dividing by 4 to get \(-12.5\).</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>Cannot calculate the mean because the numbers are negative.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Mistakes the place value column of hundred thousands with millions
response:
<Construct Name>Read and Write Large Numbers </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Numeration and Place Value </Subject Name>  
<Question>Identify the place value of the digit \(3\) in the number \(3,205,067\). </Question>  
<Correct Answer>Millions </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Hundred thousands </Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name>Write large numbers as words </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Place Value </Subject Name>  
<Question>Write the number \(305,000\) in words. </Question>  
<Correct Answer>Three hundred and five thousand </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Three million and five thousand </Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name>Comparing Large Numbers </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Number Comparison </Subject Name>  
<Question>Compare the numbers \(850,000\) and \(1,050,000\) and state which is larger. </Question>  
<Correct Answer>1,050,000 is larger than 850,000. </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>850,000 is larger because students confuse hundred thousands as millions. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes vertically opposite angles sum to 360 degrees
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Angles Formed by Intersecting Lines</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry of Intersecting Lines and Points</Subject Name>

<Question>When two lines intersect, they form four angles. If one of these angles is \(110^{\circ}\), what is the measure of the vertically opposite angle? Provide reasoning for your answer.</Question>

<Correct Answer>The measure of the vertically opposite angle is \(110^{\circ}\) because vertically opposite angles are equal.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The measure of the vertically opposite angle is \(250^{\circ}\) because the two vertically opposite angles add up to \(360^{\circ}\).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes squaring a negative number just changes the sign
response:
<Construct Name>Solving quadratic equations through factorization</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Algebra</Subject Name>  
<Question>Solve for \( x \) in the equation:  
\[ x^{2} + 6x + 9 = 0 \]  
using factorization.</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( x = -3 \) (since \((x + 3)^2 = 0\)) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( x = 3 \) \(\big(\)incorrectly assuming \(-3 \times -3 = 3\big)\) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not convert measurements to have the same units before calculating area or volume
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate the volume of a cylinder with height and diameter in different units</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Volume of Cylinders</Subject Name>
<Question>You have a cylinder with a diameter of 10 cm and a height of 200 mm. Calculate the volume of the cylinder.</Question>
<Correct Answer>The correct volume is \( \pi \times 5^2 \times 20 \), converted to cubic centimeters, which equals \( 500\pi \cm^3 \).</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>If the measurement units are not converted, it would incorrectly be calculated as \( \pi \times 5^2 \times 200 \) mm\(^3\) which equals \( 5000\pi \) mm\(^3\).</Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Calculate surface area of a triangular prism when given in different units</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Surface Area of 3D Shapes</Subject Name>
<Question>Find the surface area of a triangular prism with a base area of 20 cm\(^2\), a height of 50 mm, and side faces given as rectangles of dimensions 5 cm by 5 cm and 10 cm by 5 cm.</Question>
<Correct Answer>Convert the height to cm and calculate: \( 20 + (5 \times 5) + (5 \times 5) + (10 \times 5) = 145 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \).</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>If the measurements are added without converting, it results in: \( 20 + (5 \times 5) + (5 \times 5) + (10 \times 50) = 520 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \).</Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Calculate the perimeter of a rectangular field with sides in different units</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Perimeter</Subject Name>
<Question>A rectangular field has a length of 120 m and a width of 3000 cm. What is the perimeter of the field in meters?</Question>
<Correct Answer>The correct perimeter is \( 120 + 30 + 120 + 30 = 300 \mathrm{~m} \).</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>If not converting units, the incorrect perimeter would be \( 120 + 3000 + 120 + 3000 = 6240 \mathrm{~m} \).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Counts on by 1, when asked to count forward/backwards in a step other than 1
response:
<Construct Name> $$Count forward in steps of something other than one$$ </Construct Name>   
<Subject Name> $$Counting$$ </Subject Name>  
<Question> $$Liam is counting forward in steps of \( 3 \). He starts at the number \( 10,246 \). What is the next number he will say?$$ </Question>  
<Correct Answer> $$10,249$$ </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer> $$10,247$$ </Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name> $$Count backwards in steps of of something other than one$$ </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name> $$Counting$$ </Subject Name>  
<Question> $$Emma is counting backward in steps of \( 6 \). She starts at the number \( 8,540 \). What is the next number she will say?$$ </Question>   
<Correct Answer> $$8,534$$ </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer> $$8,539$$ </Incorrect Answer>  

<Construct Name> $$Count forward in steps of something other than one$$ </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name> $$Counting$$ </Subject Name>  
<Question> $$Olivia is counting forward in steps of \( 7 \). She starts at the number \( 15,333 \). What is the next number she will say?$$ </Question>  
<Correct Answer> $$15,340$$ </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer> $$15,334$$ </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks you apply one inverse operation to one term and the other inverse operation to the other term
response:
<Construct Name>Solving Linear Equations with Two-Step Operations</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Algebra</Subject Name>

<Question>Solve for \( x \) in the equation: \( 2x - 3 = 11 \).</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( x = 7 \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( x = 5 \)</Incorrect Answer> 

Explanation: Students might misapply inverse operations. Instead of performing addition first to both sides (to deal with the subtraction of 3), they might mistakenly subtract from one part and add to another incorrectly, leading to subtracting 3 from both terms in the equation \( 2x - 3 = 11 \) before dividing by 2.

MisconceptionName: Thinks a higher average means more consistent data
response:
<Construct Name>$$Comparing Variability in Data Sets$$</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>$$Statistics and Probability$$</Subject Name>

<Question>$$A group of students received the following scores on two different tests: 

Test A Scores: 88, 90, 92, 94, 96 \\
Test B Scores: 70, 85, 90, 95, 110 \\
Which test had the more consistent scores?$$</Question>

<Correct Answer>$$Test A is more consistent because its scores have a smaller range (96 - 88 = 8) compared to Test B's range (110 - 70 = 40).$$</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>$$Test A is more consistent because it has a higher mean (mean of Test A is 92, while Test B is 90).$$</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: adds all given dimensions when calculating area
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate the area of rectangular fields in a farming context.</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry</Subject Name>

<Question>A farmer has a rectangular field with a length of 25 meters and a width of 15 meters. What is the area of the field?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The area of the field is calculated by multiplying the length by the width: \( 25 \, \text{meters} \times 15 \, \text{meters} = 375 \, \text{square meters} \).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The area is mistakenly calculated by adding all the dimensions together instead of multiplying the length and width: \( 25 \, \text{meters} + 15 \, \text{meters} = 40 \, \text{square meters} \), which is not correct since area is not calculated by addition.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes 0 has no square root
response:
<Construct Name>Finding square roots of numbers, including zero</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Basic Algebra</Subject Name>

<Question>What are the square roots of \(0\)?</Question>

<Correct Answer>\(0\) is the only square root of \(0\), because \(0^2 = 0\).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\(0\) has no square roots because there is no number that can be multiplied by itself to equal \(0\).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes mirror line must lie on a grid line, not in between grid lines
response:
<Construct Name>Reflection across lines </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry and Symmetry </Subject Name>

<Question>Reflect the triangle with vertices \( (1, 2), (3, 4), (5, 2) \) across the line \( x = 2.5 \). What are the coordinates of the reflected triangle?</Question> 

<Correct Answer>The reflected coordinates are \( (4, 2), (2, 4), (0, 2) \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The reflected coordinates could be \( (4, 2), (2, 4), (1, 2) \) because the reflection is forced to lie on a grid line, misunderstanding the mirror line's position. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When asked for more, find the total
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate additional quantity needed </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Basic Arithmetic Operations </Subject Name>  
<Question>A bakery has baked 150 muffins. A customer wants to buy 180 muffins in total. How many more muffins should the bakery bake to meet the customer's requirement? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>30 muffins </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>180 muffins </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks they can simplify algebraic fractions by cancelling unlike variables
response:
<Construct Name>Algebraic Fraction Simplification</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Algebraic Simplification</Subject Name>  
<Question>Simplify the following algebraic fraction: \(\frac{x + 2y}{x + 3}\).</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The fraction cannot be simplified further.</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\(\frac{2y}{3}\)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes that prime numbers cannot be even
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding properties of prime numbers </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Number Theory </Subject Name>  
<Question>Which of the following numbers is a prime number? Re-evaluate your understanding of even numbers in this context.  
A) 9  
B) 2  
C) 4  
D) 15 </Question>  
<Correct Answer>B) 2 </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>No prime number is even; thus, the answer is none. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When using interpolation to estimate frequency, assumes half the frequency of the class containing the value will be above/below it, even if it is not the midpoint
response:
<Construct Name>Interpolation in frequency distribution</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Statistics</Subject Name>

<Question>In a grouped frequency distribution of people's heights, the class interval 160-170 cm contains 12 people. 
Assuming linear interpolation, estimate the number of people whose height is less than 165 cm, given that 20 people have heights less than 160 cm.</Question>

<Correct Answer>Estimate is 26 people</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Estimate is 26 + \( \frac{12}{2} = 32 \) people</Incorrect Answer>

Explanation of the answer:
- Correct answer: To correctly use interpolation, calculate the proportion of the interval up to 165 cm: it is \(\frac{165 - 160}{170 - 160} = \frac{5}{10} = 0.5\). Thus, 6 people (50% of 12) have heights between 160 and 165 cm. Therefore, a total of 20 + 6 = 26 people have heights less than 165 cm.

- Incorrect answer: The misconception leads to assuming that simply half of the class frequency (6) could be added directly to the previous cumulative total irrespective of the specific data value within the class interval, leading to overestimating at 32 people.

MisconceptionName: Does not understand the relationship between a ratio and fraction
response:
<Construct Name>Convert ratios to fractions </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Writing Ratios </Subject Name>

<Question>A fruit punch is made by mixing orange juice and pineapple juice in the ratio 2:3. What fraction of the punch is orange juice? </Question> 

<Correct Answer>\( \frac{2}{5} \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>5:2 </Incorrect Answer>



<Construct Name>Convert ratios to fractions </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Writing Ratios </Subject Name>

<Question>In a mixture of cement and sand, the ratio of cement to sand is 4:5. What fraction of the mixture is cement? </Question> 

<Correct Answer>\( \frac{4}{9} \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>4:5 </Incorrect Answer>



<Construct Name>Convert ratios to fractions </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Writing Ratios </Subject Name>

<Question>In a salad, the ratio of cucumbers to tomatoes is 7:3. What fraction of the salad is tomatoes? </Question> 

<Correct Answer>\( \frac{3}{10} \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>3:7 </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes when you plot a sequence, the line always passes through (0, 0)
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding and plotting arithmetic sequences</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Sequences and Graphs</Subject Name>

<Question>The first term of an arithmetic sequence is 3, and the common difference is 2. Plot the first five terms of this sequence on a graph with the term number on the x-axis and the term values on the y-axis. What is the equation of the line generated by these points?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The plotted points are (1, 3), (2, 5), (3, 7), (4, 9), and (5, 11). The equation of the line is \( y = 2x + 1 \).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The plotted points could inaccurately include (0, 0), leading to a misunderstanding of the series extending through the origin. Students might then incorrectly write the equation of the line as \( y = 2x \) assuming a proportional relationship through the origin.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks they had to give the new amount rather than the total percentage that the original has been increased by.
response:
<Construct Name>Calculating Total Percentage Increase</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Percentage Change</Subject Name>

<Question>An item originally costs \( £200 \). The price is increased by \( 25\% \). Then, it is further increased by \( 15\% \) of the new price. What is the total percentage increase from the original price?</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 43.75\% \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 240\% \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Incorrectly cancels what they believe is a factor in algebraic fractions
response:
<Construct Name>Factorise and simplify an algebraic fraction involving quadratic expressions</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject Name>  
<Question>Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^2 - 9}{x - 3} \)</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( x + 3 \)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( x - 3 \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes each vertical line on a box plot represents 1 piece of data
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Box Plots</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Statistics and Data Representation</Subject Name>
<Question>Given the box plot below, determine how many data points are represented by the plot:

\( \text{Minimum} = 10 \)
\( \text{Q1} = 15 \)
\( \text{Median} = 20 \)
\( \text{Q3} = 25 \)
\( \text{Maximum} = 30 \)

Assume the data is split evenly across all intervals.</Question> 
<Correct Answer>There is no fixed number of data points represented by a box plot. Box plots show the distribution of data across quartiles, the median, and can highlight outliers, but do not denote individual data points.</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The box plot represents exactly 5 data points: 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, as each vertical line is presumed to represent 1 piece of data.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes when changing an improper fraction to a mixed number you divide the numerator by 10, regardless of the denominator
response:
<Construct Name>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject Name>

<Question>Convert this into a mixed number fraction: 
\(
\frac{23}{4}
\)</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 5 \frac{3}{4} \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 2 \frac{3}{4} \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes expanding a squared expression means writing it as a set of double brackets
response:
<Construct Name>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)² </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Expanding Double Brackets </Subject Name>  
<Question>Expand and simplify:  
\((5 x + 7)^{2}\) </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\(25 x^{2} + 70 x + 49\) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\((5 x + 7)(5 x + 7)\) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes a line of reflection must be touching the original shape
response:
<Construct Name> Identify the line of reflection that maps a shape to its image </Construct Name>

<Subject Name> Transformation Geometry </Subject Name>

<Question> A rectangle, labelled "R", is positioned on a coordinate plane with its vertices at (1, 1), (1, 4), (3, 1), and (3, 4). Its image, rectangle "R'", has vertices at (5, 1), (5, 4), (7, 1), and (7, 4). Which vertical line of reflection will map rectangle \(R\) onto rectangle \(R'\)? Consider the vertical lines \( x = 0 \), \( x = 2 \), \( x = 4 \), and \( x = 3 \). </Question>

<Correct Answer> x = 4 </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer> x = 3 </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When adding fractions with identical numerators, leaves the numerator and adds the denominators
response:
<Construct Name>Addition of Fractions with Identical Numerators </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Fractions </Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the sum of \( \frac{3}{5} + \frac{3}{8} \)? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>The sum is \( \frac{3 \times 8 + 3 \times 5}{5 \times 8} = \frac{24 + 15}{40} = \frac{39}{40} \). </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The sum is \( \frac{3}{5 + 8} = \frac{3}{13} \). </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not recognise an example of the alternate segment theorem
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding the alternate segment theorem and linking angles formed by tangents and chords</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Circle Theorems</Subject Name>
<Question>Given a circle with center O, a tangent \(AB\) touches the circle at point \(P\). A chord \(PQ\) is drawn such that it intersects the circle at \(Q\). If \(\angle APQ = 40^\circ\), what is \(\angle PQB\)?</Question>
<Correct Answer>\(\angle PQB = 40^\circ\), by the alternate segment theorem, which states that the angle between the tangent and chord is equal to the angle in the alternate segment.</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\(\angle PQB = 50^\circ\), by incorrectly assuming that \(\angle PQB\) is supplementary to \(\angle APQ\) due to a misunderstanding of the circle's properties.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks x = 0 is the x axis
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding and plotting points using linear equations on a coordinate plane</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Coordinate Geometry</Subject Name>

<Question>A point \( \mathrm{P}(5, 2) \) is to be reflected across the line \( x = 0 \). What will be the coordinates of the new point \( \mathrm{P'} \) after reflection?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The correct coordinates for point \( \mathrm{P'} \) are \((-5, 2)\), since reflecting across the line \( x = 0 \) results in mirroring the x-coordinate to the negative side of the y-axis.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The incorrect coordinates for point \( \mathrm{P'} \) could be \((5, -2)\), if a student mistakenly interprets \( x = 0 \) as the x-axis (horizontal axis) and incorrectly reflects the y-coordinate instead of the x-coordinate.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not recognise parallel lines angle rules
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding the Properties of Parallel Lines and Angles</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Geometry: Parallel Lines and Angle Relationships</Subject Name>
<Question>Two parallel lines, \( AB \) and \( CD \), are intersected by a transversal \( EF \). Angle \( AEF \) is \( 120^\circ \). What is the measure of angle \( EFC \)?</Question> 
<Correct Answer>60°</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>120°</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the constant gives the y-intercept even when a line is not written in the form y = mx + c
response:
<Construct Name>Analyzing Lines from Implicit Form Equations</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Interpreting Equations of Lines Without the Slope-Intercept Form</Subject Name>
<Question>Consider the line given by the equation \( 3x + 4y = 12 \). Identify the correct statement about this line from the following options: 
- A: The y-intercept is 12.
- B: The y-intercept is 3.
- C: The y-intercept is 4. 
- D: None of the above.  
</Question>
<Correct Answer>D </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>A </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Finds unit price but doesn't multiply up for number in question
response:
<Construct Name>Use percentages to find the discount amount on multiple items</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Percentages</Subject Name>

<Question>A store is offering a 20% discount on notebooks that originally cost $5 each. If you buy 8 notebooks, how much total discount do you get?</Question>

<Correct Answer>$8</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>$1</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks 1 squared is 2
response:
<Construct Name>Perform Basic Arithmetic Operations with Integers</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Simplifying Algebraic Expressions</Subject Name>
<Question>Simplify the expression: \( 3x^2 - 4x + 1^2 \) when \( x = 1 \).</Question>
<Correct Answer>\( 3(1)^2 - 4(1) + 1^2 = 3(1) - 4 + 1 = 0 \)</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( 3(1)^2 - 4(1) + 1^2 = 3(1) - 4 + 2 = 1 \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Has increased by the value of the first value, rather than the difference
response:
<Construct Name>Percentage Increase Calculations</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Percentage Increase</Subject Name>  
<Question>A shop sells a shirt for \( £ 50 \) and then increases its price by \( 20 \% \). Later, the shop owner wants to apply another \( 20 \% \) increase on the increased price. What is the new price of the shirt?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The new price is \( £ 72 \). </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The new price is \( £ 80 \). </Incorrect Answer>  

Explanation: The misconception here is taking the second increase of \( 20\% \) from the original price (\( £ 50 \)) instead of from the increased price. For the correct solution:

1. First increase: \( 20\% \) of \( £ 50 \) is \( £ 10 \), making the shirt \( £ 60 \).
2. Second increase: \( 20\% \) of \( £ 60 \) is \( £ 12 \), making the shirt \( £ 72 \).

In the misconception, the second increase was wrongly calculated as \( 20\% \) of the original \( £ 50 \) price, leading to an additional \( £ 10 \), making the shirt \( £ 80 \).

MisconceptionName: Has taken the percentage from the original
response:
<Construct Name>Using percentages to solve multi-step problems</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Compound Interest Problems</Subject Name>

<Question>A bank account has £2000. The interest rate is \( 5\% \) per annum. After 2 years, how much interest is earned? (Assume compound interest.)</Question>

<Correct Answer>The correct interest earned is approximately £205. (\( \text{Total Amount} = 2000 \times (1 + 0.05)^2 = 2205\), so the interest is \( 2205 - 2000 = 205 \))</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Students might incorrectly calculate the interest by only taking \( 5\% \) twice from the original amount: \( 2000 \times 0.05 \times 2 = 200 \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks the movement of the top number in a column vector is vertical, and the bottom number is horizontal rather than the other way round
response:
<Construct Name>Translate points using a column vector </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Translation and Vectors </Subject Name>  
<Question>Given a point \( A \) at coordinates (6, 3), translate it using the vector \( \left(\begin{array}{c}4 \\ -2\end{array}\right) \). What are the coordinates of the new point \( A' \)? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( A' \) is at (10, 1) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( A' \) is at (4, 1) </Incorrect Answer>  

Misconception: Students may confuse vectors as representing vertical and horizontal movements incorrectly. In this specific exercise, they may interpret the top number as vertical movement, decreasing the vertical position incorrectly instead of adjusting the horizontal position.

MisconceptionName: Does not know that sample size affects reliability
response:
<Construct Name>Compare relative frequencies in order to determine which prediction is likely to be more reliable </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Experimental Probability and Relative Frequency </Subject Name>

<Question>A company is testing a new product and wants feedback. They survey \( 30 \) customers in City \( C \) who tried the product. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ City C } \\
\hline Like the product? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 21 \) \\
\hline No & \( 9 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} In City \( D \), they survey \( 120 \) customers who tried the product. \begin{tabular}{|cc|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ City D } \\
\hline Like the product? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 88 \) \\
\hline No & \( 32 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which city's results are more reliable based on the sample size? </Question> 

<Correct Answer>City D </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>City C </Incorrect Answer>

response:

What should replace the star? </Question>

What should replace the star? </Question>

What should replace the star? </Question>

What should replace the star? </Question>

MisconceptionName: When adding or subtracting surds, believes the numbers under the root and the numbers in front should both be added or subtracted
response:
<Construct Name>Adding and subtracting surds</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Surds and Indices</Subject Name>
<Question>\( \sqrt{5} + 3\sqrt{5} = ? \)</Question>
<Correct Answer>\( 4\sqrt{5} \)</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( \sqrt{20} \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Mixes up squaring with dividing by 2
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate the square of a fraction</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Squares and Fractions</Subject Name>

<Question>\( \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}=? \)</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( \frac{1}{4} \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{1}{1} \) or \( 1 \) </Incorrect Answer>



<Construct Name>Calculate the area of a square</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry: Areas and Volumes</Subject Name>

<Question>The side length of a square is 10 units. What is the area of the square?</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 100 \text{ square units} \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 5 \text{ square units} \)</Incorrect Answer>



<Construct Name>Calculate the square of a negative number</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Squares of Numbers</Subject Name>

<Question>\((-4)^{2}=? \)</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 16 \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( -2 \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate the area of a triangle where side lengths and height are given in the same units </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Area of Triangles </Subject Name>

<Question>Determine the area of the triangle \( \triangle ABC \), given its base \( AB \) is 8 cm, side \( AC \) is 6 cm, and its height from \( AC \) to \( AB \) is 4 cm. </Question>

<Correct Answer>The area of the triangle is \( \frac{1}{2} \times 8 \, \text{cm} \times 4 \, \text{cm} = 16 \, \text{cm}^2 \). </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The area of the triangle is \( \frac{1}{2} \times 8 \, \text{cm} \times 6 \, \text{cm} = 24 \, \text{cm}^2 \). </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Only multiplies the numerical terms when expanding a bracket
response:
<Construct Name>$$Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable$$ </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>$$Expanding Single Brackets$$ </Subject Name>
<Question>$$
4(3 x+2)-5(x-8) \equiv A x+B
$$

What is the value of \( A \) ? </Question> 
<Correct Answer>$$7$$ </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>$$4$$ </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks adding the same value to each side makes shapes similar
response:
<Construct Name>Determine if two triangles are similar based on their side lengths </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Triangle Similarity Criteria </Subject Name>

<Question>Sara and John are examining two triangles to determine if they are similar. Sara has a triangle with side lengths 3 cm, 4 cm, and 5 cm. John has a triangle with side lengths 6 cm, 8 cm, and 9 cm. Are these triangles similar? </Question>

<Correct Answer>No, these triangles are not similar because the sides do not have the same ratio. </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Yes, these triangles are similar because you add 3 to each side of the smaller triangle to get the sides of the bigger one. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the numerator stays the same when calculating a second pick of the same type without replacement on a tree diagram
response:
<Construct Name>Probability of Consecutive Events with Replacement and Without Replacement</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Probability and Tree Diagrams</Subject Name>
<Question>You have a bag containing 5 red balls and 3 blue balls. If you pick two balls consecutively without replacement, what is the probability that both balls are red?</Question>
<Correct Answer>The probability of picking the first red ball is \(\frac{5}{8}\). After one red ball is drawn without replacement, the probability of picking another red ball is \(\frac{4}{7}\). Therefore, the probability of picking two red balls consecutively is \(\frac{5}{8} \times \frac{4}{7} = \frac{20}{56} = \frac{5}{14} \).</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The student might incorrectly think that the probability of picking the second red ball also remains \(\frac{5}{8}\), so they would calculate the probability as \(\frac{5}{8} \times \frac{5}{8} = \frac{25}{64} \).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Finds 10% of an amount rather than the percentage being asked
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate percentage increase or decrease</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Percentages and Ratios</Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the result when a price of \( \$50 \) is increased by \( 30\% \)?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( \$65 \)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( \$55 \)</Incorrect Answer>  

Explanation:
Students might calculate \(10\%\) of \( \$50 \) as \( \$5 \) and mistakenly use this result instead of finding \(30\%\), which would be \( \$15 \). Therefore, they increase the original price by \( \$5 \), yielding an incorrect total of \( \$55 \).

MisconceptionName: Does not recognise metres as a unit of length
response:
<Construct Name>Identify a unit of length </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Perimeter Calculations </Subject Name>
<Question>Tom calculated the perimeter of his rectangular garden and got an answer of \( 450 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 450 \color{yellow} \bigstar \) </Question> 
<Correct Answer>\( L \) </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( m \) </Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Identify a unit of length </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Geometric Shapes </Subject Name>
<Question>Linda measured the sides of a triangle and calculated its total perimeter as \( 270 \).

Behind the star she has written the units that she used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 270 \color{yellow} \bigstar \) </Question> 
<Correct Answer>\( c m^3 \) </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( m \) </Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Identify a unit of length </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Circumference of a Circle </Subject Name>
<Question>Brian found the circumference of a circular track to be \( 314 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 314 \color{yellow} \bigstar \) </Question> 
<Correct Answer>\( g \) </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>\( m \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks the fraction bar means multiply rather than divide
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding the operations with fractions in rational expressions</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Algebra - Rational Expressions</Subject Name>  
<Question>Simplify the expression: \( \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{9}{2} \)</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\(3\)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\(1\)</Incorrect Answer>  

The correct approach for this problem is to multiply the numerators together and the denominators together as required in rational expression multiplication. However, a student who misunderstands the fraction bar as a multiplication symbol might try to incorrectly interpret the expression by setting up an operation between only the numerators or only the denominators as multipliers separately, leading to an incorrect answer of 1, which stems from a misinterpretation of how fractions interact.

MisconceptionName: Believes every direct or inverse proportion question uses the formula p=kq
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding and solving problems involving inverse variation where p varies inversely as q</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Variation and Proportions</Subject Name>

<Question>If \( p \) varies inversely as \( q \), and \( p = 10 \) when \( q = 4 \), find the value of \( p \) when \( q = 8 \).</Question>

<Correct Answer>The relationship can be represented by \( p = \frac{k}{q} \). First, find the constant \( k \) when \( p = 10 \) and \( q = 4 \): \( 10 = \frac{k}{4} \rightarrow k = 40 \). Then, substitute \( q = 8 \) to find \( p \): \( p = \frac{40}{8} = 5 \).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Using the misconception formula \( p = kq \), and given \( p = 10 \) when \( q = 4 \): \( 10 = k \times 4 \rightarrow k = 2.5 \). Then, for \( q = 8 \), this incorrect approach gives \( p = 2.5 \times 8 = 20 \).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Confuses x and y axes
response:
<Construct Name>Identify and sketch transformations of functions on a graph</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Graphing and Transformations</Subject Name>  
<Question>Sketch the graph of the function \( f(x) = 2(x - 3)^2 + 1 \), and state the vertex of the parabola.</Question>  
<Correct Answer>The graph should be a parabola opening upwards with the vertex at (3, 1). The transformation shifts the standard \( x^2 \) graph to the right 3 units and up 1 unit.</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The graph is incorrectly sketched with the transformation applied to the y-axis instead, showing a vertex at (1, 3). While the graph is shifted up 1 unit, the horizontal shift is misinterpreted as a vertical shift, confusing x and y axes.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the gradient of a speed-time graph is the distance
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding and interpreting graphs: Speed-time graphs</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Kinematics in Physics and Mathematics</Subject Name>

<Question>A car accelerates from rest along a straight road. The speed-time graph of the car is a straight line passing through the origin with a constant gradient. What does this gradient represent?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The gradient of the speed-time graph represents the acceleration of the car.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The gradient of the speed-time graph represents the distance traveled by the car.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes that the cumulative frequency of an interval of grouped data can be used as the cumulative frequency for any value in that interval
response:
<Construct Name>Interpret cumulative frequency graphs for grouped data</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Statistics</Subject Name>

<Question>Given the cumulative frequency table below, what is the cumulative frequency for the value 50?

| Interval       | Cumulative Frequency |
|----------------|----------------------|
| 40 - 50        | 23                   |
| 50 - 60        | 40                   |
| 60 - 70        | 58                   |

Use this to interpret the cumulative frequency graph accurately.</Question>

<Correct Answer>The cumulative frequency for the value 50 is 23 as it marks the end of the interval \'40 - 50\'.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The cumulative frequency for the value 50 is 40, as it falls within the interval \'50 - 60\', so we use that interval's cumulative frequency.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring acute angles
response:
<Construct Name>Measuring angles with a protractor</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Geometry</Subject Name>
<Question>Measure the angle ABC with a protractor. Is the angle acute, right, or obtuse?</Question>
<Correct Answer>The angle ABC measures 45 degrees, which is an acute angle.</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The angle ABC measures 135 degrees, which is an obtuse angle.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes we can only take the square root of a perfect square
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding irrational numbers and their properties</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Algebra</Subject Name>

<Question>The square root of which of the following numbers results in an irrational number? Choose the correct option: 
A) 36 
B) 48 
C) 64 
D) 81</Question>

<Correct Answer>B) 48</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>None of the above, as all these numbers need to be perfect squares to have a square root.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks index notation represents repeated addition rather than repeated multiplication
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Exponents and Powers</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Algebra - Exponentiation</Subject Name>  
<Question>Simplify \( 3^4 \).</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 3^4 = 3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3 = 81 \)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 3^4 = 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 = 12 \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes to find the proportion of a pie chart sector you do frequency/sum of other frequencies rather than frequency/overall total
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate the proportion of data represented by a sector in a pie chart</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Pie Chart Analysis</Subject Name>

<Question>A company conducted a survey about favorite fruits among its employees. The results are as follows: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Fruit & Frequency \\
\hline Apples & \( 30 \) \\
\hline Bananas & \( 10 \) \\
\hline Oranges & \( 15 \) \\
\hline Grapes & \( 5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What is the proportion of employees who prefer apples?</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( \frac{30}{30+10+15+5} = \frac{30}{60} = 0.5 \) or \( 50\% \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{30}{10+15+5} = \frac{30}{30} = 1 \) or \( 100\% \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the gradients of perpendicular lines are reciprocals of the same sign
response:
<Construct Name>Identify perpendicular lines using slope-intercept form</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Perpendicular Lines</Subject Name>

<Question>Which of the following lines is perpendicular to 
\[
y = -\frac{4}{3}x + 5 \text{?}
\]</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( y = 2 + \frac{3}{4}x \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( y = -\frac{3}{4}x + 6 \)</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the number of sides gives the order of rotational symmetry
response:
<Construct Name>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Polygons </Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the order of rotational symmetry for a regular hexagon? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>6 </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>4 </Incorrect Answer>  

Misconception: Believes the number of sides gives the order of rotational symmetry

<Construct Name>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Properties of Polygons </Subject Name>  
<Question>Determine the order of rotational symmetry for a triangle. </Question>  
<Correct Answer>3 </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>2 </Incorrect Answer>  

Misconception: Believes the number of sides gives an order of rotational symmetry

<Construct Name>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometric Transformations </Subject Name>  
<Question>How many times does a regular pentagon map onto itself in one full rotation (360 degrees)? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>5 </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>5 </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Assumes that opposite angles in a quadrilateral sum to 180 degrees
response:
<Construct Name>Find missing angles in a cyclic quadrilateral </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Angles in Circular Geometry </Subject Name>

<Question>In a cyclic quadrilateral \( ABCD \), the measure of angle \( A \) is \( 80^{\circ} \). If angle \( C \) is opposite angle \( A \), what is the measure of angle \( C \)?</Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 100^{\circ} \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 100^{\circ} \) because opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral are supplementary (they sum to \(180^{\circ}\)), while the incorrect understanding might mistakenly apply this consistently to all quadrilaterals.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Divides when converting to a larger unit
response:
<Construct Name>Understand unit conversion by multiplying or dividing based on size of units </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Measurement and Conversion </Subject Name>

<Question>Sarah wants to convert 500 centimeters to meters. She recalls a rule that involves dividing or multiplying by a conversion factor. She decides to divide 500 by 100 to convert the measurement.

Is Sarah's conversion correct? If not, what should she do? </Question>

<Correct Answer>Yes, Sarah's conversion is correct. To convert centimeters to meters, you need to divide by 100. So, \( \frac{500}{100} = 5 \) meters. </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>No, Sarah's conversion is incorrect. She should multiply 500 by 100 to convert it to 50000 meters. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When using the capture-recapture method of sampling, believes you add the number marked first to the number caught second and add that to the number marked second to get the best estimate of population size
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding the Capture-Recapture Method for Estimating Population Size</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Statistics</Subject Name>

<Question>A biologist wants to estimate the total number of fish in a lake. On day 1, she catches 100 fish, marks them, and releases them back into the water. On day 2, she catches 150 fish, out of which 30 are marked. Using the capture-recapture method, estimate the fish population in the lake. A student thinks the best estimate is found by adding the numbers: \(100 + 150 + 30\). What is the correct population estimate?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The correct estimate is 500 fish. Using the capture-recapture formula, \(\text{Total Population} = \frac{(\text{Number marked first} \times \text{Number caught second})}{\text{Number marked second}}\), we have \(\frac{100 \times 150}{30} = \frac{15000}{30} = 500\).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>280 fish (by adding 100 + 150 + 30).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When solving simultaneous equations thinks that identical terms in given equations can be eliminated by either adding or subtracting.
response:
<Construct Name>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Simultaneous Equations </Subject Name>

<Question>Consider the pair of simultaneous equations given below:

\(\begin{array}{l} 
4x - 3y = 12 \\ 
4x + 5y = 28 
\end{array}\)

Alex suggests that if you add the two equations together, you will eliminate the \(4x\) terms.

Jamie suggests that if you subtract the two equations, you will eliminate the \(4x\) terms.

Who is correct?</Question> 

<Correct Answer>Only Jamie </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Both Alex and Jamie </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not understand where to place inputs/ operations/ outputs when drawing a function machine
response:
<Construct Name>For a given input find the output of a function machine </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Function Machines </Subject Name>

<Question>Cally wants to use the function machine below to solve this problem:

I think of a number, add 4, double it, and the answer is \( 18 \).

Which of the following should replace the star? ![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and has "input" written above it. The next 2 rectangles are empty and the final rectangle on the right is the output and has a purple star inside it.]() </Question>

<Correct Answer>\( 18 \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( +4 \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Adds instead of multiplies when calculating total frequency
response:
<Construct Name>Probability with multiple events</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Probability</Subject Name>
<Question>Consider a bag containing different colored balls: 2 red balls, 3 blue balls, and 5 green balls. If you were to draw one ball at random and then, without replacing it, draw another ball, what is the probability of drawing first a red ball and then a blue ball?</Question>
<Correct Answer>The correct probability is calculated by multiplying the probabilities of the two independent events: P(Red) = 2/10, and P(Blue after Red) = 3/9. Therefore, the probability is (2/10) * (3/9) = 1/15.</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The incorrect approach involves adding the probabilities of the events: P(Red) + P(Blue) = 2/10 + 3/10 = 5/10 = 1/2.</Incorrect Answer>

<Construct Name>Area and perimeter of shapes</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Geometry</Subject Name>
<Question>Jane has a rectangular garden that measures 4 meters by 7 meters. She wants to calculate how much fencing she needs to buy to enclose her garden. What should she consider to find the correct length of fencing?</Question>
<Correct Answer>To find the perimeter of the rectangle, Jane should use the formula: Perimeter = 2 * (Length + Width) = 2 * (4 + 7) = 22 meters.</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>To find the perimeter, Jane incorrectly adds the sides together once: 4 + 7 = 11 meters.</Incorrect Answer>

<Construct Name>Arithmetic sequences</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Sequences and series</Subject Name>
<Question>In an arithmetic sequence, the first term is 3, and the common difference is 2. What is the sum of the first 5 terms?</Question>
<Correct Answer>The sum of the first 5 terms of an arithmetic sequence is calculated using the formula: Sum = (Number of terms/2) * (First term + Last term). Here, the sequence is 3, 5, 7, 9, 11. So, Sum = (5/2) * (3 + 11) = 35.</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>The mistake occurs when adding instead of multiplying: 3 + 5 + 7 + 9 + 11 = 35, but then further adding up the sequence numbers themselves, mistakenly leading to 3 + 5 + 7 + 9 + 11 + 5 = 40.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not know the meaning of corresponding
response:
<Construct Name>$$Understanding Corresponding Angles$$</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>$$Properties of Parallel Lines and Transversals$$</Subject Name>

<Question>$$Line \( l \) and line \( m \) are parallel. A transversal \( t \) intersects them at points \( A \) and \( B \), creating angles \( \angle 1, \angle 2, \angle 3, \) and \( \angle 4 \) at point \( A \), and angles \( \angle 5, \angle 6, \angle 7, \) and \( \angle 8 \) at point \( B \). If \( \angle 1 \) measures \( 50^\circ \), what is the measure of \( \angle 5 \)?$$</Question>

<Correct Answer>$$50^\circ$$</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>$$130^\circ$$</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks the subtraction sign means divide
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding basic arithmetic operations</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Subtraction and Division</Subject Name>  
<Question>Calculate the difference \(c - d\), where \(c = 20\) and \(d = 5\).</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\(15\)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\(4\)</Incorrect Answer>  

This confusion often happens when students mistakenly interpret the subtraction sign as an instruction to divide, leading them to compute \(20 \div 5\) to arrive at an incorrect answer of \(4\), instead of correctly subtracting to get \(15\).

MisconceptionName: Fails to use the properties of simple shapes to work out missing lengths
response:
<Construct Name>Understand properties of right triangles to determine side lengths</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry</Subject Name>

<Question>Given a right triangle with one leg \( a = 3 \) cm and hypotenuse \( c = 5 \) cm, find the length of the other leg \( b \).</Question>

<Correct Answer>The length of the other leg \( b \) is 4 cm, using the Pythagorean theorem: \( b = \sqrt{c^2 - a^2} = \sqrt{5^2 - 3^2} = \sqrt{25 - 9} = \sqrt{16} = 4 \) cm.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Not enough information</Incorrect Answer>

---

<Construct Name>Determine sides of similar triangles using proportions</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Similar Triangles</Subject Name>

<Question>Triangle \( \triangle ABC \) is similar to triangle \( \triangle DEF \). If \( AB = 6 \) cm, \( AC = 10 \) cm, and \( DE = 9 \) cm, find the length of \( DF \).</Question>

<Correct Answer>The length of \( DF \) is 15 cm, using the proportional relationship: \( \frac{AB}{DE} = \frac{AC}{DF} \rightarrow \frac{6}{9} = \frac{10}{DF} \rightarrow DF = \frac{10 \times 9}{6} = 15 \) cm.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Not enough information</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks the first term in a sequence is the term before the sequence begins (0th term)
response:
<Construct Name>Generate terms of an alternating sequence from the nth term rule </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Linear Sequences (nth term) </Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the first term of the sequence defined by the rule:
\[
(-1)^n \cdot (3n + 2)
\] </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\(-1(3 \cdot 1 + 2) = -5\) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\((3 \cdot 0 + 2) = 2\) </Incorrect Answer>

<Construct Name>Identify the first positive term in a decreasing sequence </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Sequences-Others </Subject Name>  
<Question>Identify the first positive term of the sequence given by:
\[
10 - 4n
\] </Question>  
<Correct Answer>The first positive term is \(10\) when \(n=1\). </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The first positive term is \(14\) assuming \(n=0\). </Incorrect Answer>

<Construct Name>Find the number of terms in a sequence up to a given value </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Linear Sequences (nth term) </Subject Name>  
<Question>How many terms in the sequence \(3n + 2\) are less than 20?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\(n=5\) is the largest integer before the term reaches 20, thus the number of terms is \(5\). </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Starting from \(n=0\), \((3 \times 0 + 2)\) counts, leading to \(6\) terms. </Incorrect Answer>

<Construct Name>Identify the position-to-term rule of a linear sequence </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Sequences-Others </Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the nth-term rule for the sequence:
\[
12, 8, 4, 0, \ldots
\] </Question>  
<Correct Answer>The nth-term rule is \(16 - 4n\). </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The nth-term rule is \(12 - 4n\). </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When adding or subtracting surds, simplifies the surds correctly but puts the digits in the answer the wrong way round
response:
<Construct Name>Combining like surds</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Simplifying Surds</Subject Name>
<Question>\(\sqrt{8} + 2\sqrt{2}\)

Simplify the expression. </Question>
<Correct Answer>\(4\sqrt{2}\) </Correct Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks 1 square metre = 100,000 cubic centimetres
response:
<Construct Name>Unit Conversion between Area and Volume</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Measurement and Conversion</Subject Name>

<Question>If a floor has an area of 2 square meters, how many cubic centimeters would this be if mistakenly calculated using the incorrect conversion?</Question>

<Correct Answer>Conversion between area and volume directly is incorrect. An area of 2 square meters is 20,000 square centimeters (since 1 square meter equals 10,000 square centimeters). However, cubic centimeters cannot be directly obtained from square meters without additional dimension information.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Using the incorrect assumption that 1 square meter equals 100,000 cubic centimeters, the area of 2 square meters would be wrongly calculated as:
\[ 2 \times 100,000 = 200,000 \text{ cubic centimeters} \]</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Describes position to term rule using term to term rule
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding sequence rules</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Arithmetic Sequences</Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the position-to-term rule for the sequence 3, 6, 9, 12, ...?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\[ t(n) = 3n \]</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The term-to-term rule is "add 3." Therefore, students might write it as \[ t(n) = t(n-1) + 3 \], wrongly identifying it as the position-to-term rule. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When writing a function as a function machine confuses the input and the output.
response:
<Construct Name>Comparing function machines and equations</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Algebraic Functions</Subject Name>  
<Question>Match the linear function \( f(x) = 2x - 3 \) to its function machine representation.</Question>  
<Correct Answer>![A function machine with 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. "𝑥" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "✕ 2" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "- 3" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "f(x)"]()</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>![A function machine with 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. "f(x)" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "✕ 2" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "- 3" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "𝑥"]()</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not recognise that subtracting a larger number from a smaller number will give a negative answer
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Subtraction of Larger Numbers from Smaller Numbers</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Basic Arithmetic Operations</Subject Name>

<Question>Sarah has 7 apples, and she gives 10 apples to her friend John. How many apples does Sarah have left?</Question>

<Correct Answer>Sarah has \(-3\) apples. This indicates she owes 3 apples, as subtracting 10 from 7 gives a negative result: \(7 - 10 = -3\).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>Sarah has 3 apples left. This answer mistakenly suggests that \(7 - 10\) equals 3, not recognizing that the proper result is negative when subtracting a larger number from a smaller number.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks you need to include the total as well as the individual parts when asked to write a ratio
response:
<Construct Name>Convert verbal problems into ratio expressions </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Writing Ratios </Subject Name>

<Question>In a class, there are \(7\) boys and \(5\) girls. Write the ratio of boys to girls.</Question>

<Correct Answer>\(7:5\) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\(7:5:12\) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Divides by (n-2) rather than n when finding an interior angle
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate interior angles of polygons </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometry </Subject Name>  
<Question>What is the measure of each interior angle of a regular hexagon? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 120^\circ \) </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 135^\circ \) </Incorrect Answer>

**Explanation:**
To find the measure of each interior angle of a regular polygon with \( n \) sides, you should use the formula:  
\[
\text{Interior Angle} = \frac{(n-2) \times 180^\circ}{n}
\]

For a hexagon (\( n = 6 \)), the correct calculation is:  
\[
\text{Interior Angle} = \frac{(6-2) \times 180^\circ}{6} = \frac{720^\circ}{6} = 120^\circ
\]

The misconception arises when students mistakenly divide by \( n-2 \) instead of \( n \), leading to:
\[
\frac{(6-2) \times 180^\circ}{6-2} = \frac{720^\circ}{4} = 180^\circ
\]
This results in dividing \( 720^\circ \) by \( 4 \) instead of 6, leading to the incorrect result.

MisconceptionName: When dividing involving a power of 10, gives an answer 10 times bigger than it should be
response:
<Construct Name>Divide whole numbers by 100 </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Division and Place Value </Subject Name>

<Question>What is the value of:
\[
500 \div 100
\] </Question> 

<Correct Answer>\( 5 \) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( 50 \) </Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Divide fractions by 10 </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Fractions and Decimals </Subject Name>

<Question>What is the value of:
\[
\frac{3}{4} \div 10
\] </Question> 

<Correct Answer>\(\frac{3}{40}\) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\(\frac{3}{4}\) </Incorrect Answer>


<Construct Name>Simplify expressions with powers of 10 </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Algebra </Subject Name>

<Question>Find the value of:
\[
(10x) \div 100
\] where \(x = 50\). </Question> 

<Correct Answer>\(5x = 5(50) = 250\) </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\(50x = 50(50) = 2500\) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes you can subtract from inside brackets without expanding when solving an equation
response:
<Construct Name>Solving equations involving the distributive property </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Algebra </Subject Name>  
<Question>A student is tasked with solving the following equation:  
\(
3(x-2) + 7 = 22
\)

The student decides to simplify the equation as follows:  
\(
3x - 6 + 7 = 22
\)

What should the correct first step be? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>Use the distributive property to expand: \( 3x - 6 + 7 = 22 \), leading to \( 3x + 1 = 22 \). </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>Choose to subtract without properly using the distributive property: \( 3x = 28 \). </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: In inverse proportion, believes k is the total of the two variables
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding the constant of proportionality in inverse variation </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Inverse Proportion </Subject Name>  
<Question>In a scenario where the number of workers on a project changes inversely with the number of days it takes to complete the project, if 10 workers can complete the project in 15 days, how many days will it take 25 workers to complete the same project? Use the constant \( k \) to model the relationship and provide your answer. </Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 6 \) days </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 35 \) days </Incorrect Answer>  

In the correct calculation, the constant of proportionality \( k \) is determined by multiplying the number of workers with the days, i.e., \( k = 10 \times 15 = 150 \). In an inverse relation, \( k = \text{workers} \times \text{days} = 150 \). With 25 workers, the days required is \( \frac{150}{25} = 6 \).  

The misconception occurs if the student incorrectly assumes that \( k \) is the sum of the workers and days, \( k = 10 + 15 = 25 \), and then tries to use this incorrect \( k \) to solve \( \frac{25}{25} = 1 \), subsequently leading to including all day by wrongly reading the total result to get an incorrect answer by adding incorrectly calculated workers or days.

Misunderstandings like these often arise from misinterpretation of the constant \( k \) in proportional relationships, assuming it represents a simple sum rather than considering it as a multiplicative factor.

MisconceptionName: Does not realise that if the horizontal and vertical measurements of a diagonal line segment switch it remains the same size
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding properties of diagonal line segments</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry in Coordinate Planes</Subject Name>

<Question>A diagonal of a rectangle on the coordinate plane has its endpoints at \( A(1, 4) \) and \( B(5, 7) \). 

If you switch the horizontal and vertical distances between these two points, what are the new coordinates of point \( B \)? 

Does the length of the diagonal line segment change?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The horizontal distance is \(5 - 1 = 4\) and the vertical distance is \(7 - 4 = 3\). 

If these are switched, the coordinates change from \( (5, 7)\) to \( (5, 4 + 4) = (5,8) \). 

The distance remains the same because the square of the lengths \((3^2 + 4^2)\) gives the same value by the Pythagorean theorem.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The new coordinates would be \( (4, 7) \), and the length of the diagonal changes.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Finds area of whole circle rather than area of sector

<Subject Name>Geometry - Areas of Circles and Sectors </Subject Name>  
<Question>Find the area of a sector with a central angle of 60 degrees and a radius of 5 cm. </Question>

<Incorrect Answer>\( \pi (5^2) = 25\pi \approx 78.54 \text{ square cm} \) </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks a Fibonacci sequence must start with 1, 1
response:
<Construct Name>Recognising Generalised Fibonacci Sequences</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Sequences and Series</Subject Name>

<Question>Consider the following sequence: \( 2, 2, 4, 6, 10, 16, \ldots \)

Is this a Fibonacci sequence? Explain why or why not.</Question>

<Correct Answer>Yes, this is a Fibonacci sequence. A Fibonacci sequence is defined by the recurrence relation where each term is the sum of the two preceding ones, starting with any two initial numbers. In this case, starting with 2 and 2, the sequence follows the pattern: \( 2, 2, (2+2=4), (2+4=6), (4+6=10), (6+10=16), \ldots \)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>No, this is not a Fibonacci sequence because it does not start with 1, 1.</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes that repeated percentage change is equivalent to a single change by the sum of the percentages
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Successive Percentage Changes </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Percentage Calculations </Subject Name>  
<Question>A store is running a two-day sale. On the first day, all items are discounted by \( 10\% \), and on the second day, items on sale are given an additional discount of \( 15\% \) on the newly reduced price. If an item originally costs $100, what is its final price after both discounts? </Question>   
<Correct Answer>The final price is $76.50. </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The final price is $75. </Incorrect Answer>  

**Explanation:**  
- **Correct Calculation:** First discount of \( 10\% \) on $100 reduces the price to $90. Then, \( 15\% \) of $90 is $13.50, so the final price is $76.50.  
- **Incorrect Understanding:** The student incorrectly sums the percentages, applying a \( 25\% \) reduction to the original $100 directly to get $75.

MisconceptionName: Does not understand that a remainder can be written as a fraction
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding remainders in the context of fractions</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Basic Division with Fractions</Subject Name>  
<Question>Divide \( 29 \) by \( 6 \) and express the result as a mixed number.</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\( 4 \frac{5}{6} \)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\( 4 \) remainder \( 5 \)</Incorrect Answer>  

Misconceptions often arise during division when students interpret remainders as whole numbers rather than as parts of fractions, leading to misunderstandings in expressing the results with mixed numbers.

response:

<Correct Answer>\(2(n + 4) = 30\)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\(2n + 4 = 30\)</Incorrect Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\(n - 5^2 = 16\)</Incorrect Answer>

<Correct Answer>\(5(n + 3) = 40\)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\(5n + 3 = 40\)</Incorrect Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\( \frac{3}{9} \)</Incorrect Answer>  

Misunderstanding Explanation: Students might see mismatched denominators and fail to convert \( \frac{2}{3} \) into an equivalent fraction, such as \( \frac{4}{6} \), to make the addition easier. Instead, they might incorrectly add the numerators and denominators separately without first finding a common denominator.

The graph shows a line passing through the points (4, 10) and (8, 18)]()$$</Question>

MisconceptionName: Thinks they find the length of a line between 2 points by adding coordinates, rather than subtracting
response:
<Construct Name>Calculating Distance Between Two Points in a Coordinate Plane</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Distance Formula and Coordinate Geometry</Subject Name>

<Question>What is the distance between the points A(3, 4) and B(7, 1) in the coordinate plane?</Question>

<Correct Answer>The distance is \(\sqrt{(7 - 3)^2 + (1 - 4)^2} = \sqrt{4^2 + (-3)^2} = \sqrt{16 + 9} = \sqrt{25} = 5\).</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The distance is \(\sqrt{(7 + 3)^2 + (1 + 4)^2} = \sqrt{10^2 + 5^2} = \sqrt{100 + 25} = \sqrt{125} = 5\sqrt{5}\).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the length of the arms influence the size of the angle
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding angles and their properties independent of the lengths </Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Geometry - Properties of Angles </Subject Name>

<Question>A triangle ABC has sides \( AB = 5 \, \text{cm} \), \( BC = 7 \, \text{cm} \), and \( AC = 10 \, \text{cm} \). Given that side \( AB \) is extended to a length of \( 8 \, \text{cm} \) while keeping angle \( \angle ABC \) constant, does the size of angle \( \angle ABC \) change? Explain why or why not. </Question>

<Correct Answer>The size of angle \( \angle ABC \) does not change. Angle measures are determined by the relative positioning of the arms and not their lengths. Therefore, altering the length of \( AB \) does not affect \( \angle ABC \). </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The size of angle \( \angle ABC \) increases because extending arm \( AB \) to \( 8 \, \text{cm} \) makes the arm longer, thus affecting the angle size. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b = a^2 + the original constant

<Question>When completing the square, what constant should be added to transform the quadratic expression into a perfect square trinomial?
\[ 
x^{2} + 6x + 3 \equiv (x + 3)^{2} + \Delta 
\]</Question>

<Correct Answer>\(\Delta = -6\)</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>\(\Delta = 12\)</Incorrect Answer>

<Question>A school wants to know the average number of hours its students spend on homework each week. They decide to conduct a survey. Which group should they ask to get a random sample of the student population? </Question>

<Correct Answer>The school should select a random sample of students from all grades and classes to provide an unbiased representation of the entire student body. </Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The school should select only students from the top-performing classes, as they are more likely to complete their homework regularly. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Draws false conclusion from a pie chart
response:
<Construct Name>Interpret data representations </Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Statistics </Subject Name>
<Question>A pie chart shows the favorite fruit of a group of students. The fruits and their corresponding percentages are: 
Apples 25%, Bananas 30%, Oranges 20%, Grapes 25%. If 200 students were surveyed, how many students prefer Grapes? </Question>
<Correct Answer>50 students prefer Grapes, as 25% of 200 students is \( \frac{25}{100} \times 200 = 50\). </Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>60 students prefer Grapes, as the student wrongly assumes that since Bananas and Grapes both have the same 
percentage, they should add the numbers or similar types of errors leading to false logic. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not know how to divide a fraction by an integer
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding the division of fractions</Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Fractions and Decimals</Subject Name>  
<Question>If you have \(\frac{3}{4}\) of a pizza and you want to divide it equally among three people, how much pizza does each person get?</Question>  
<Correct Answer>\(\frac{3}{4} \div 3 = \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{1}{3} = \frac{3}{12} = \frac{1}{4}\)</Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>\(\frac{3}{4} \div 3 = \frac{3}{4} \times 3 = \frac{9}{4}\)</Incorrect Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The elevation shows a top-down view, depicting the arrangement of rooms or objects on the floor plan without any vertical details.</Incorrect Answer>

response:
<Construct Name> $$Operations with Algebraic Expressions$$ </Construct Name>

<Subject Name> $$Algebra$$ </Subject Name>

<Correct Answer> $$4x + 20$$ </Correct Answer>

MisconceptionName: Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order, unless brackets are used
response:
<Construct Name>Order of Operations</Construct Name>
<Subject Name>Basic Arithmetic Operations</Subject Name>
<Question>Solve the following expression: \( 8 + 2 \times 3 - 4 \div 2 \).</Question>
<Correct Answer>The correct sequence of operations based on the BODMAS/BIDMAS rule is:

1. Multiply: \(2 \times 3 = 6\)
2. Divide: \(4 \div 2 = 2\)
3. Add: \(8 + 6 = 14\)
4. Subtract: \(14 - 2 = 12\)

So, the correct answer is \( 12 \).</Correct Answer>
<Incorrect Answer>If calculations are done strictly left to right without considering order of operations:

1. Add: \(8 + 2 = 10\)
2. Multiply: \(10 \times 3 = 30\)
3. Subtract: \(30 - 4 = 26\)
4. Divide: \(26 \div 2 = 13\)

Thus, the incorrect answer is \( 13 \).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Believes the mean is something divided by the number of categories given
response:
<Construct Name>Calculate the mean of a dataset </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Statistics </Subject Name>  
<Question>In a recent school survey, students were asked their favorite fruits and the results were:

- Apples: 15  
- Bananas: 12  
- Oranges: 9  
- Grapes: 6  

What is the mean number of votes per fruit? </Question>  
<Correct Answer>The mean number of votes per fruit is \( \frac{15 + 12 + 9 + 6}{4} = \frac{42}{4} = 10.5 \). </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>The mean number of votes per fruit is \( \frac{42}{4} = 10.5 \), but the misunderstanding would lead someone to incorrectly divide the total number of votes by the number of fruit categories without properly calculating: \( \frac{42}{4} = 10.5 \). However, if students don't sum the numbers correctly and think the mean is a different operation or ignore summation altogether, they might incorrectly calculate: \( \frac{42}{8} = 5.25 \), taking each fruit as a separate division. </Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Does not connect rotational symmetry to number of sides/vertices
response:
<Construct Name>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape </Construct Name>  
<Subject Name>Geometry </Subject Name>  
<Question>Which of the following shapes has rotational symmetry order \( 6 \)? A) Equilateral Triangle B) Regular Hexagon C) Square D) Rectangle </Question>  
<Correct Answer>B) Regular Hexagon </Correct Answer>  
<Incorrect Answer>A) Equilateral Triangle </Incorrect Answer>  

Misconception Explanation: Students may incorrectly associate the number of sides of the equilateral triangle (3) as correlating with the potential for a higher order of rotational symmetry due to misunderstanding that more sides always indicate more symmetry. However, rotational symmetry order is determined by whether a shape looks the same after a certain degree of rotation, not simply by the number of sides. An equilateral triangle repeats every 120°, thus having an order of symmetry of 3, while a regular hexagon repeats every 60°, having an order of symmetry of 6.

MisconceptionName: Believes the frequency of the midpoint of a group is half the total frequency of the group
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Grouped Frequency Distribution</Construct Name>

<Subject Name>Statistics</Subject Name>

<Question>The table below shows the distribution of ages of students in a class. Determine the frequency of the midpoint for the age group 10-14.

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Age Group} & \text{Frequency} \\
\hline
5-9 & 8 \\
10-14 & 12 \\
15-19 & 10 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]</Question>

<Correct Answer>The frequency of the midpoint is not directly calculated and does not equal half of the group frequency. Instead, the midpoint itself is 12, but only a frequency of 12 is recorded for the entire group, without splitting it at the midpoint.</Correct Answer>

<Incorrect Answer>The frequency of the midpoint for the age group 10-14 is \( \frac{12}{2} = 6 \).</Incorrect Answer>

MisconceptionName: Thinks the fraction 1/n can express sharing n items between any number of people
response:
<Construct Name>Understanding Fractions in Dividing Quantities</Construct Name>
